metadata.description: Official Discogs credit role classifications using their Heading and Subheading structure (normalized)

General.name: Artwork By
General.notes: NON-LINKED CREDIT - This credit will not create any new artist, nor link to any artist page. Use "Artwork" for a linked credit.

General.name: Photography
General.notes: NON-LINKED CREDIT - This credit will not create any new artist, nor link to any artist page. Use "Photography By" for a linked credit.

General.name: Executive Producer
General.notes: NON-LINKED CREDIT - This credit will not create any new artist, nor link to any artist page. Use "Executive-Producer" for a linked credit.

General.name: Other
General.notes: NON-LINKED CREDIT - This credit will not create any new artist, nor link to any artist page. To be used for roles credited on the release that are not musical or technical, and should not be linked, for example, catering personnel, drivers etc. Please see the note here regarding 'Thank You' type credits.

General.name: Written By
General.notes: NON-LINKED CREDIT - This credit will not create any new artist, nor link to any artist page. This is a special unlinked role that can be used to group all credited writers of the music and display their names as formatted on the release. e.g. Lennon/McCartney. If the full name of the artist is displayed on the release you must use the linked Written-By credit, but can also use the unlinked credit if the formatting is of significance. The Artist Name Variation function should also be considered when deciding which credit should be used.

General.name: Written-By
General.notes: This is the new version of the Written By credit that is linked. It is used in the same way as all other linked credits. Note the dash '-', it is vital it is entered exactly this way.

General.name: Adapted By
General.notes: Somewhat similar to Arranged By.

General.name: Beats
General.notes: A diverse role that signifies a contribution to the instrumental component of a track or a release. On some releases, it is synonymous with Producer, on others it can range from sampling to Drum Programming to playing a traditional, typically percussion-oriented, instrument.

General.name: Cadenza
General.notes: (Italian for cadence) Generically, an improvised or written-out ornamental passage played or sung by a soloist or soloists, usually in a "free" rhythmic style, and often allowing for virtuosic display. Often refers to a portion of a concerto in which the orchestra stops playing, leaving the soloist to play alone in free time (without a strict, regular pulse) and can be written or improvised, depending on what the composer specifies. Please also include the instrument they are playing, as a separate credit, if noted on the release. See Soloist.

General.name: Composed By
General.notes: Person who writes the musical composition or melody to songs (valid for all genres)

General.name: Copyist
General.notes: Employed by the music industry to produce written parts for individual musicians from an orchestral score or composer's manuscript.

General.name: Instrumentation By
General.notes: For orchestral and other groups, refers to the selection of instruments to play the different parts.

General.name: Libretto By
General.notes: The text used in an extended musical work such as an opera, operetta, masque, sacred or secular oratorio and cantata, musical, and ballet. The term "libretto" is also sometimes used to refer to the text of major liturgical works, such as mass and requiem.

General.name: Lyrics By
General.notes: Person who writes the lyrics to songs

General.name: Programmed By
General.notes: (also programming) - Working a computer or electronic instrument in order to create a sound or sequence of notes (see also Drum Programming, Sequenced By)

General.name: Score
General.notes: This is almost the same as Composed By

General.name: Sequenced By
General.notes: The act of programming a computer, drum machine, or other sequencer to play a sequence of musical events.

General.name: Songwriter
General.notes: Use if the artist is credited as "Songwriter" or with "Song(s) By" or "Song(s) written by" on the release

General.name: Transcription By
General.notes: Notating a piece or a sound which was previously unnotated, or rewriting a piece of music, either solo or ensemble, for another instrument or other instruments than which it was originally intended.

General.name: Translated By
General.notes: For roles that involve translating lyrics from one language to another. This role is for translations that are used in the audio work only. For Liner Notes translation and the like, please use brackets such as "Liner Notes [Translated By]" (or whatever the role was) instead.

General.name: Words By
General.notes: Appears on many records as an alternative to "Lyrics By".

General.name: Hosted By
General.notes: An alternative credit for someone who presents a show, mixtape etc.

General.name: Presenter
General.notes: If no specific credit is apparent on the release, an artist with a following 'Presents' joiner must be credited with 'Presenter' in the credits section, with specific tracks indicated if relevant

General.name: Concertmaster
General.notes: (also concert-master, leader, concertmistress) The leader of the first violin section of a symphony orchestra. Any violin solo in an orchestral work is played by the concertmaster (except in the case of a concerto, in which case guest soloists may be heard).

General.name: Concertmistress
General.notes: (also concertmaster, leader) The leader of the first violin section of a symphony orchestra. Any violin solo in an orchestral work is played by the concertmaster (except in the case of a concerto, in which case guest soloists may be heard).

General.name: Conductor
General.notes: Conducting is the act of directing a musical performance by way of visible gestures. Orchestras, choirs, concert bands and other musical ensembles are often conducted. The principal conductor of an orchestra or opera company is sometimes referred to as a music director or chief conductor, or by the German word, Kapellmeister. Conductors of choirs or choruses are sometimes referred to as choral director, chorus master, or choirmaster, particularly for choirs associated with an orchestra. Conductors of military bands and other bands may hold the title of bandmaster, or drum major. Respected senior conductors are sometimes referred to by the Italian word, maestro ("master").

General.name: Contractor
General.notes: (also fixer) - A musical casting assistant, he is the person who hires the musicians to form an orchestra / choir / etc for a specific piece.

General.name: Directed By
General.notes: Can be used for all types of music or non-music (radio plays etc) Director roles, but not to be used for video roles.

General.name: Leader
General.notes: Also Band Leader or Orchestra Leader, the head of a group, orchestra, or other music ensemble who often takes on tasks such as organization, musical arrangement, hiring and firing musicians, musical direction, and other group based tasks.

General.name: Repetiteur
General.notes: (also Répétiteur) - In opera, the person responsible for coaching singers and playing the piano for music and production rehearsals. In ballet, a répétiteur teaches the steps and interpretation of the roles to some or all of the company

General.name: Collected By
General.notes: Similar to Compiled By

General.name: Compilation Producer
General.notes: Use instead of Other [Compilation Producer] or Producer [Compilation]

General.name: Editor
General.notes: Record company staff job, often synonymous to producer or supervisor, and not to be confused with technical editing ("cutting") of audio material.

General.name: Executive-Producer
General.notes: This is the linked version of the legacy unlinked "Executive Producer" role.

General.name: Producer
General.notes: In the music industry, a record producer has many roles, among them controlling the recording sessions, coaching and guiding the musicians, organizing and scheduling production budget and resources, and supervising the recording, mixing and mastering processes. This has been a major function of producers since the inception of sound recording, but in the latter half of the 20th century producers have also taken on a wider entrepreneurial role.

General.name: Recording Supervisor
General.notes: Follows the orchestral scores during the recording process in a very critical way, in order to spot any mistakes that musicians or a conductor wouldn't notice or simply ignore. Common on classical recordings. For example on Deutsche Grammophon, it is "Aufnahmeleitung".

General.name: Reissue Producer
General.notes: Someone who oversees the production of a reissued release.

General.name: Remix
General.notes: The creative manipulation of some elements of the original track into a different but derivative musical piece.

General.name: DJ Mix
General.notes: DJ Mix - to be used for crediting the creation of a mixed or partially mixed release. Don't confuse this credit with "Mixed By" (which is used for the artist that mixes the multitrack music to the final release mixdown) or "Remix".

General.name: Artwork
General.notes: Replaces the non-linked "Artwork By" credit, which can still be used if you are not sure of the artist to credit.

General.name: Assemblage
General.notes: Any form of composite assembly or 3-d form.

General.name: CGI Artist
General.notes: Computer-generated imagery

General.name: Cover
General.notes: A generic credit for cover artwork and / or design.

General.name: Film Director
General.notes: This umbrella role is for any visual director, for example, a music video director or a director of a concert recording. An alternative name may be "video director", but the role usually appears on video / DVD releases as "directed by".

General.name: Film Producer
General.notes: Not to be confused with the audio producer role. Audio producers "Producer" credit may be listed on video / DVD releases as "Concert Sound Production" or "DVD Post Production Producer" or similar.

General.name: Lettering
General.notes: For artistic lettering that is not calligraphy.

General.name: Model
General.notes: Only use this credit when the person is explicitly credited as Model (or similar wording). This is not meant to simply capture the person in a photo, but a specific credited role.

General.name: Photography By
General.notes: Replaces the non-linked "Photography" credit, which can still be used if you are not sure of the artist to credit.

General.name: Production Manager
General.notes: Responsible for realizing the visions of the producer and the director or choreographer for stage productions. Please do not confuse with 'Product Manager'.

General.name: Realization
General.notes: denotes final stages of visual design

General.name: Sleeve
General.notes: A generic credit for sleeve artwork and / or design.

General.name: Videography
General.notes: The production of video material.

General.name: VJ
General.notes: Video Jockey - Someone who mixes video footage and graphics.

General.name: Abridged By
General.notes: The person who condenses text from a book to be used as an audio book

General.name: Adapted By (Text)
General.notes: Similar to Abridged By but in this case although the text has been condensed down it will also be rearranged and have additional text also. More commonly used for Radioplays.

General.name: Interviewee
General.notes: The person getting interviewed

General.name: Music Librarian
General.notes: The area of librarianship that pertains to music collections and their development, cataloging, preservation and maintenance, as well as reference issues connected with musical works and music literature.

General.name: Read By
General.notes: The act of reading from a book or other manuscript.

General.name: Script By
General.notes: Used for radio plays etc.

General.name: Voice Actor
General.notes: Used for actors in radio plays etc.

General.name: A&R
General.notes: Short for Artists and repertoire, the person that is responsible for talent scouting and overseeing the artistic development of recording artists. They also acts as a liaison between artists and the record label.

General.name: Coordinator
General.notes: (also Co-ordination / Coordination / Co-ordinator / Coordinator)

General.name: Product Manager
General.notes: The person who looks after the creation and promotion of the physical release. Please don't confuse with 'Production Manager', which is a mainly theatrical role.

General.name: Vocal Coach
General.notes: Also voice coach: A music teacher, usually a piano accompanist, who helps singers prepare for a performance, often also helping them to improve their singing technique and take care of and develop their voice.

General.name: Crew
General.notes: Stage Crew, Road Crew etc.

General.name: DAW
General.notes: (also Digital Audio Workstation)

General.name: Lacquer Cut By
General.notes: An engineer cuts an acetate/dubplate blank with a lathe. Exclusive to grooved formats but not DMM. Can often be identified by a unique etching or stamp in the runout grooves. If in doubt, then please ask in the database forum section.

General.name: Luthier
General.notes: Person who makes or repairs stringed instruments.

General.name: Mastered By
General.notes: A catch-all term for any role performed by an engineer (or team of engineers) during the post-mixing audio process.

General.name: Mixed By
General.notes: This credit is for the person that mixes the multitrack music to the final release mixdown, NOT for a mix by a DJ (which should be credited as "DJ Mix"), nor a remix type production (which should be credited as "Remix")

General.name: Plated By
General.notes: An engineer dips a lacquer into a chemical bath for an electrolysis galvanic plating process. If in doubt, then please ask in the database forum section.

General.name: Remastered By
General.notes: An engineering / production role where previously released audio is put through the mastering process again, often to improve upon previous efforts, taking into account more up to date technology, different tastes, and changed requirements of the mastering process, for example for digital releases.

General.name: Technician
General.notes: General, non-specific role for technical credits, use the brackets [...] to add more information if available.

General.name: Tracking By
General.notes: The act of recording, most likely overdubbing and building up the track.

General.name: Transferred By
General.notes: (also Audio Transfer, CD Transfer, Digital Transfer) - Technical transferring of audio from one medium to another, for example, analog tape to digital.

General.name: Tuner
General.notes: The person who tunes an instrument, most commonly a concert piano or organ

General.name: Cantor
General.notes: A leader of sung worship in various religions. In In formal Jewish worship, a cantor is a person who sings solo verses or passages to which the choir or congregation responds.

General.name: Choir
General.notes: A company of singers, esp. an organized group employed in church service or sings sacred music.

General.name: Chorus
General.notes: An ensemble which performs the non-soloist parts of an opera or musical theatre production (or sometimes an oratorio). Chorus can mean a section of a song, but it should not be used in this way for the credits. The specific instrument should be listed if possible, otherwise a generic role should be used, such as Performer [Chorus].

General.name: Contralto Vocals
General.notes: A few popular music enthusiasts define the contralto and alto separately, as the contralto having an especially dark range, from the D above low C to Tenor C, which is essentially a female of tenor range, while alto is a voice with a range from G below middle C to the F an eleventh above middle C, and is closer to the mezzo-soprano. The majority however define contralto and alto as synonyms, and assign the adjectives light and dark, with a dark alto being a female of tenor range, while a light alto, commonly referred to as simply alto, to include mezzo-sopranos as well.

General.name: Coro
General.notes: Literally 'chorus' in Spanish, the coro in most Latin music has fixed melody and lyrics. Most coros feature two or three parts, rarely more, moving in parallel lines. The coro singer's function in a band is more like an instrumentalist's than a singer's.

General.name: Eefing
General.notes: A traditional folksy style of human hillbilly beatboxing that has been around for over 100 years in Appalachia, USA.

General.name: Humming
General.notes: A hum is a sound made by singing a wordless tone with the mouth completely closed, forcing the sound to emerge from the nose.

General.name: Joik
General.notes: Also yoik: the traditional form of singing of the Sami people of northern Scandinavia. A joik evokes a person, animal, or place. There are two styles: vuolle of the South Sami, and luohti the North Sami.

General.name: Kakegoe
General.notes: (also 掛け声) kakegoe are usually words of encouragement for the musicians, singers, or dancers performing with the music. They are also used to cue different parts of a musical piece.

General.name: MC
General.notes: A Master of Ceremonies or MC (sometimes spelled emcee), sometimes called a compère or an MJ for "microphone jockey," MC became associated with what would change to become known as the rapper. Also is the host of an official public or private staged event or other performance, where the MC usually presents performers, speaks to the audience, and generally keeps the event moving

General.name: Mezzo-soprano Vocals
General.notes: A mezzo-soprano (meaning "half soprano" in Italian) is a female singer with a range usually extending from the A below middle C to the A two octaves above (i.e. A3-A5, middle C = C4).

General.name: Overtone Voice
General.notes: Overtone Voice, also known as overtone singing, throat singing, overtone chanting, or harmonic singing, is a type of singing in which the singer manipulates the harmonic resonances (or formants) created as air travels from the lungs, past the vocal folds, and out the lips to produce a melody. Throat singing is both a generic and a specific term. Generally, the term is applied to any singing style which entails the application of a harsh voice or some other constriction, although it is sometimes incorrectly applied to unconstricted overtone singing. Specifically, the term refers to a type of Central Asian overtone singing.

General.name: Toasting
General.notes: Toasting, chatting, or DJing (not to be confused with the more common use of DJ outside of Jamaica to mean someone who plays records) is the act of talking or chanting over a rhythm or beat. Most common in the Reggae genre.

General.name: Yodeling
General.notes: (also yodelling, jodeling) A form of singing that involves singing an extended note which rapidly and repeatedly changes in pitch from the vocal or chest register (or "chest voice") to the falsetto/head register; making a high-low-high-low sound. This vocal technique is used in many cultures throughout the world.

Drums and percussion.name: Adufe
Drums and percussion.notes: A traditional rectangular frame drum from Portugal. The frame is usually made of pine with goat's skin stretched over it, and contains some small seeds or stones to enhance the sound.

Drums and percussion.name: Afoxé
Drums and percussion.notes: An Afro Brazilian musical instrument composed of a gourd (cabaça) wrapped in a net in which beads or small plastic balls are threaded. It looks like the xequerê, but the afoxé is smaller. The instrument is shaken to produce its musical noise.

Drums and percussion.name: Agogô
Drums and percussion.notes: (or agogo bell) - A multiple bell used in samba percussion ensembles. It is made of metal with each bell a different size. The most common arrangement is two bells attached by a U shaped piece of metal.

Drums and percussion.name: Alegre
Drums and percussion.notes: Also hembra, mayor or quitambre: a drum about 70cm high made from a tree trunk used to accompany the melody in cumbia, involving complex rhythmic improvisations.

Drums and percussion.name: Ashiko
Drums and percussion.notes: A drum shaped like a truncated cone and meant to be played with bare hands. Played throughout sub-Saharan Africa and the Americas. In eastern Cuba, it is known as boku. Unlike the sounds of a Djembe whose body offers two main tones, the straight edges offer a continuum of tones depending on how close to the center of the head the drum is struck. Some consider the ashiko to be male and the djembe female.

Drums and percussion.name: Bata
Drums and percussion.notes: A sacred drum used by the Yoruba (of West Africa) and in the Caribbean. In Cuba, batá consists of a set of three drums: iyá ("mother drum"), the largest; itótele ("father") and okónkolo ("baby"), the smallest.

Drums and percussion.name: Bell Tree
Drums and percussion.notes: A percussion instrument, consisting of vertically nested inverted metal bowls. The bowls, placed on a vertical rod, are arranged in order of pitch (inexactly). The number of bowls can vary between approximately 14 and 28. An effective glissando is done by sliding a triangle beater, a glockenspiel mallet, or a xylophone mallet down the tree.

Drums and percussion.name: Bells
Drums and percussion.notes: For all types of ringing metal. Note that Temple Bells and Tubular Bells have their own credits.

Drums and percussion.name: Bendir
Drums and percussion.notes: A frame drum used as a traditional instrument throughout North Africa, more specifically in Morocco

Drums and percussion.name: Bodhrán
Drums and percussion.notes: A frame drum ranging in anywhere from 10" to 26" in diameter, with most drums measuring from 14" to 18". The sides of the drum are 3 1/2" to 8" deep. A skin head is tacked to one side.

Drums and percussion.name: Body Percussion
Drums and percussion.notes: May be performed on its own or as an accompaniment to song. The folk traditions of many countries include the use of body percussion. Examples of these include Indonesian saman, Ethiopian armpit music, palmas in flamenco, and the hambone from the United States.

Drums and percussion.name: Bombo
Drums and percussion.notes: (also Bombo Legüero) An Argentine drum traditionally made of a hollowed tree trunk and covered with cured skins of animals such as goats, cows or sheep.

Drums and percussion.name: Bones
Drums and percussion.notes: A percussion instrument consisting of a pair of animal bones, or pieces of wood or a similar material.

Drums and percussion.name: Buhay
Drums and percussion.notes: (also Bugai, Buhai, Berebenytsia, Bika, Buga, Bochka) - A friction drum. It consists of a conical barrel (sometimes a wooden bucket). At one end a sheep membrane is stretched with a hole in this skin's center. Through this hole a tuft of horse hair with a knot at one end is passed. Usually two performers are needed to operate the instrument, one to hold the instrument, the other to pull the horsehair with moistened fingers.

Drums and percussion.name: Buk
Drums and percussion.notes: A traditional Korean drum. It is barrel-shaped, with a round wooden body covered on both ends with animal skin.

Drums and percussion.name: Cabasa
Drums and percussion.notes: Also called Afuche. Similar to the shekere, is a percussion instrument that is constructed with loops of steel ball chain wrapped around a wide cylinder. The cylinder is fixed to a long, narrow wooden or plastic handle.

Drums and percussion.name: Caixa
Drums and percussion.notes: A brazilian snare drum

Drums and percussion.name: Calabash
Drums and percussion.notes: A percussion instrument, of the family of idiophones, consisting of a dried half calabash, of large size, that is struck with the palms, fingers, wrist or objects to produce a variety of percussive sounds.

Drums and percussion.name: Caxixi
Drums and percussion.notes: A Brazilian percussion instrument consisting of a closed basket with a flat-bottom filled with seeds or other small particles.

Drums and percussion.name: Chácaras
Drums and percussion.notes: A percussion instrument from the Canary Islands similar to castanets but larger.

Drums and percussion.name: Chak'chas
Drums and percussion.notes: Pre-Columbian percussion instrument, made from the hooves of small animals.

Drums and percussion.name: Chinchín
Drums and percussion.notes: Maracas made from the shell of fruits from morro trees

Drums and percussion.name: Ching
Drums and percussion.notes: A small bowl-shaped finger cymbals of thick and heavy bronze, with a broad rim commonly used in Cambodia and Thailand.

Drums and percussion.name: Clap Sticks
Drums and percussion.notes: A pair of wooden sticks used in indigenous Australian music by clapping them together.

Drums and percussion.name: Claves
Drums and percussion.notes: Also called Clavés or Clave, a pair of short (about 20-8 cm), thick dowels. Traditionally they were made of wood, but nowadays they are also made of fibreglass or plastics. When struck they produce a bright clicking noise. Claves are sometimes hollow and carved in the middle to amplify the sound.

Drums and percussion.name: Cuica
Drums and percussion.notes: Brazilian friction drum

Drums and percussion.name: Cultrun
Drums and percussion.notes: A ceremonial drum used by the Mapuche in Chile.

Drums and percussion.name: Daf
Drums and percussion.notes: (also دف) A frame drum used in Middle East,Armenia, Pakistan, Turkey, Tajikistan, Azerbaijan and India. Some dafs are equipped with rings or small cymbals, making them a form of tambourine.

Drums and percussion.name: Darbouka
Drums and percussion.notes: Darbouka – Also darbuka, darabouka, darabuka, derbake, debuka, derbekkeh, tarabuka, tarabaki: a single-head drum with a goblet-shaped body most commonly used in the traditional music of Egypt, and also across North Africa. See also Goblet Drum.

Drums and percussion.name: Davul
Drums and percussion.notes: A large double-headed drum that is played with mallets.

Drums and percussion.name: Dhol
Drums and percussion.notes: A double-sided sided barrel drum (straight barrels also exist) played mostly as an accompanying instrument to the traditional Punjabi dance of Bhangra, the traditional dance of Gujarat, Raas, and the religious music of Sufism, Qawwali.

Drums and percussion.name: Dholak
Drums and percussion.notes: (also ਢੋਲਕੀ, ढोलक, dholaki, dhool) A North Indian, Pakistani and Nepalese double-headed hand-drum.

Drums and percussion.name: Dikanza
Drums and percussion.notes: A notched length of bamboo rubbed by a wooden stick, used in Angolan music.

Drums and percussion.name: Djembe
Drums and percussion.notes: Also jembe: a rope-tuned skin-covered goblet drum from West Africa

Drums and percussion.name: Doira
Drums and percussion.notes: A medium-sized frame drum with jingles

Drums and percussion.name: Dunun
Drums and percussion.notes: (also: djun-djun) A West African cylindrical drum.

Drums and percussion.name: Finger Snaps
Drums and percussion.notes: The act of creating a cracking/clicking sound with one's fingers by building tension between the thumb and the middle or index finger, and then moving the middle or index finger so it hits the palm of one's hand.

Drums and percussion.name: Flamenco Dance
Drums and percussion.notes: Variants include Bailaor(a) (Spanish for flamenco dancer), Taconeo (rhythmic patterns created chiefly by the heel), Zapateo/Zapateado (an interplay of heel, toe and sole intended to produce elaborate sounding rhythms). The percussive rhythm made by the dancer's shoes makes the performer not just a dancer, but also a percussive musician.

Drums and percussion.name: Frame Drum
Drums and percussion.notes: A drum that has a drumhead width greater than its depth. Usually the single drumhead is made of rawhide or man-made materials.

Drums and percussion.name: Friction Drum
Drums and percussion.notes: (also Rommelpot) - A percussion instrument consisting of a single membrane stretched over a sound box, whose sound is produced by the player causing the membrane to vibrate by friction.

Drums and percussion.name: Frottoir
Drums and percussion.notes: Relative to Washboard

Drums and percussion.name: Ganzá
Drums and percussion.notes: A cylindrically shaped Brazilian rattle, can be either a hand-woven basket, or a metal canister which is filled with beads, metal balls, pebbles, or other similar items. Those made from metal produce a particularly loud sound.

Drums and percussion.name: Ghatam
Drums and percussion.notes: (also Gatham) - An earthenware pot used in indian classical music

Drums and percussion.name: Ghungroo
Drums and percussion.notes: (also گھنگرو‎, घुँघरू, Ghunghroo, Ghunghru, Ghungur, Salangai) small metallic bells strung together, a musical anklet tied to the feet of classical Indian dancers, and also Pakistani dancers.

Drums and percussion.name: Goblet Drum
Drums and percussion.notes: Also Called: Darabouka, Darbuka, Doumbek, Dumbek, Dumbeg, Tarambuke, Tombak, Zarb, Dumbelek, Tabla (not to be confused with Indian Tabla), Derbekkeh, Toumbeleki

Drums and percussion.name: Gong
Drums and percussion.notes: A wide variety of metal percussion instruments.

Drums and percussion.name: Gong Chime
Drums and percussion.notes: A series of tuned pot gongs, usually played in ensembles in south-east Asian music. Examples are: kulintang, gangsa (Bali/Java), reyong (Bali), bonang (Java), totobuang (Maluku Islands).

Drums and percussion.name: Güira
Drums and percussion.notes: A scraped metal percussion instrument in Latin American music. Similar to the güiro, which is made from a gourd.

Drums and percussion.name: Guiro
Drums and percussion.notes: The güiro is a scraped percussion instrument in Latin American music made from an open-ended, hollow gourd.

Drums and percussion.name: Hihat
Drums and percussion.notes: (also Hi-Hat) Two cymbals that are mounted on a stand, one on top of the other, and clashed together using a pedal on the stand. A narrow metal shaft or rod runs through both cymbals into a hollow tube and connects to the pedal. The top cymbal is connected to the rod with a clutch, while the bottom cymbal remains stationary resting on the hollow tube. The height of the top-cymbal (open position) is adjustable.

Drums and percussion.name: Hosho
Drums and percussion.notes: Zimbabwean percussion instrument

Drums and percussion.name: Hyoshigi
Drums and percussion.notes: Japanese wooden percussion instrument

Drums and percussion.name: Idiophone
Drums and percussion.notes: An idiophone is any musical instrument which creates sound primarily by way of the instrument vibrating itself, without the use of strings or membranes. Idiophones are probably the oldest type of musical instrument (not counting the human voice). Most percussion instruments which are not drums are idiophones. Struck idiophones (sometimes called concussion idiophones) include most of the non-drum percussion instruments familiar in the west. They include all idiophones which are made to vibrate by being hit, either directly with a stick or hand (like the wood block, singing bowl, triangle or marimba), or indirectly, by way of a scraping or shaking motion (like maracas or flexatone). Various types of bells fall into both categories. The other three sub-divisions are rarer. They are plucked idiophones, such as the jew's harp, amplified cactus, music box or mbira (lamellophone / thumb piano); blown idiophones, of which there are a very small number of examples, the Aeolsklavier being one; and friction idiophones, such as the singing bowl, glass harmonica, glass harp, turntable, verrophone, daxophone, styrophone, musical saw, or nail violin (a number of pieces of metal or wood rubbed with a bow). A number of idiophones that are normally struck, such as vibraphone bars and cymbals, can also be bowed.

Drums and percussion.name: Jaggo
Drums and percussion.notes: A double-headed hourglass-shaped drum generally played with one stick and one hand.

Drums and percussion.name: Janggu
Drums and percussion.notes: Also called janggo or changgo. A percussion instrument used in most kinds of Korean traditional music. It is made from a hollow wooden body and two leather skins. The two sides produce sounds of different pitch and tone.

Drums and percussion.name: Jing
Drums and percussion.notes: A large gong

Drums and percussion.name: K'kwaengwari
Drums and percussion.notes: Metal idiophone.

Drums and percussion.name: Ka
Drums and percussion.notes: Percussion from the Réunion Island (and from Guadeloupe and Martinique)

Drums and percussion.name: Kagura Suzu
Drums and percussion.notes: 神楽鈴 (Japanese bells)

Drums and percussion.name: Kanjira
Drums and percussion.notes: (also ganjira) is a South Indian frame drum, an instrument of the tambourine family

Drums and percussion.name: Karkabas
Drums and percussion.notes: Metal double castanets of the Gnawa (Morocco). Also known as krakebs or garagab.

Drums and percussion.name: Kebero
Drums and percussion.notes: A double-headed, conical hand drum from Ethiopia, Sudan and Eritrea, primarily used in weddings, funerals and other ceremonies. The instrument is made from a hollowed-out section of a tree trunk with a piece of animal hide stretched over each end.

Drums and percussion.name: Kendang
Drums and percussion.notes: lso Kendhang, Gandang, Gendrang: a two-headed drum used in the Gamelan and Kulintang ensembles of the Indonesian Archipelago.

Drums and percussion.name: Khartal
Drums and percussion.notes: This wooden clapper is a Ghana Vadya which has discs or plates that produce a clinking sound when clapped together.

Drums and percussion.name: Khurdak
Drums and percussion.notes: An Indian percussion instrument, a type of tambourine

Drums and percussion.name: Kynggari
Drums and percussion.notes: A small gong used primarily in folk music.

Drums and percussion.name: Lion's Roar
Drums and percussion.notes: A membranophone instrument that has a drum head and a cord or horsehair passing through it. The home-made lion's roar is a drum that sits on the floor. The cord then makes friction with the drumhead as it is moved back and forth. It makes a noise effect like lion roaring.

Drums and percussion.name: Llamador
Drums and percussion.notes: Also macho or yamaró: a drum used to mark the beat or cadence in cumbia, with a conical body 30 to 40cm high. There are two types of llamador drums: "de pecho", which rests on the lap and played with one hand, and "de pie" which is played standing and with both hands.

Drums and percussion.name: Monkey stick
Drums and percussion.notes: (also Mendoza, Mendozer, Murrumbidgee River Rattler, Lagerphone) a pole affixed to a heavy boot at the base. Metal "jingles", commonly beer-bottle tops, are fastened at intervals along the shaft.

Drums and percussion.name: Mridangam
Drums and percussion.notes: A percussion instrument from South India. It is the primary rhythmic accompaniment in a Carnatic music ensemble. Alternate spellings include mridanga, mrudangam, mrdangam, mrithangam miruthangam and mirudhangam.

Drums and percussion.name: Naqareh
Drums and percussion.notes: Also naqqāra, nagara, nagada, nakers or naccaire: a Middle Eastern drum with a rounded back and a hide head, usually played in pairs.

Drums and percussion.name: Pandeiro
Drums and percussion.notes: Brazilian tambourine with a tuned skin.

Drums and percussion.name: Quijada
Drums and percussion.notes: Also charrasca: the jawbone of a donkey used in Latin American music. It is either struck with a stick to make the teeth rattle or the stick pulled across the teeth, creating a rasping sound.

Drums and percussion.name: Rainstick
Drums and percussion.notes: A long, hollow tube which is filled with small baubles such as beads or beans and has small pins arranged helically on its inside surface. When the stick is upended, the beads fall to the other end of the tube, making a sound reminiscent of a rainstorm as they bounce off the pins. The rainstick is generally used to create atmospheric sound effects or as a percussion instrument.

Drums and percussion.name: Ravanne
Drums and percussion.notes: A large drum like the bodhrán of Irish music, used to mark the main rhythm in the séga music of Mauritius.

Drums and percussion.name: Reco-reco
Drums and percussion.notes: A scraping instrument that is held in one hand whilst the other scrapes its springs with a metal stick.

Drums and percussion.name: Repinique
Drums and percussion.notes: A two-headed Brazilian drum used in samba baterias (percussion ensembles)

Drums and percussion.name: Rototoms
Drums and percussion.notes: Drums which have no shell. They consist of a single head in a die-cast zinc or aluminum frame. Unlike most other drums, they have a variable definite pitch.

Drums and percussion.name: Sabar
Drums and percussion.notes: A traditional drum from Senegal that is generally played with one hand and one stick.

Drums and percussion.name: Shaker
Drums and percussion.notes: A shaker may comprise a container, partially full of small loose objects such as beads, which create the percussive sounds as they collide with each other, the inside surface, or other fixed objects inside the container.

Drums and percussion.name: Shakubyoshi
Drums and percussion.notes: 笏拍子 (Japanese percussion instrument)

Drums and percussion.name: Shekere
Drums and percussion.notes: A percussion instrument from Africa, consisting of a dried gourd with beads woven into a net covering the gourd. Throughout the continent it is called different things, such as the lilolo, axatse (Ghana), Xequeré, and chequere.

Drums and percussion.name: Shuitar
Drums and percussion.notes: Percussion instrument

Drums and percussion.name: Singing Bowls
Drums and percussion.notes: Also known as a Himalayan bowl or cup gong. The instrument is made of metal, played by hitting, striking, or slowly rubbing/stirring a wooden striker/mallet within or on the top outer surface of the bowl

Drums and percussion.name: Sistrum
Drums and percussion.notes: A hand-held metal frame with hinged loops that is shaken. It originated in ancient Egypt and is now a liturgical instrument in the Ethiopian Orthodox Church.

Drums and percussion.name: Skratjie
Drums and percussion.notes: Surinam drum & percussion instrument, a bass drum with two cymbals mounted on top.

Drums and percussion.name: Slapstick
Drums and percussion.notes: A wooden percussion instrument consisting of two flat pieces of wood, hinged at one end, which, when snapped together produce a slapping sound.

Drums and percussion.name: Slit Drum
Drums and percussion.notes: A hollow percussion instrument, usually a log drum of bamboo or wood, that is made with one or more slits in it.

Drums and percussion.name: Snare
Drums and percussion.notes: A drum with strands of snares made of curled metal wire, metal cable, plastic cable, or gut cords stretched across the drumhead, typically the bottom. Pipe and tabor and some military snare drums often have a second set of snares on the bottom (internal) side of the top (batter) head to make a "brighter" sound, and the Brazilian caixa commonly has snares on the top of the upper drumhead.

Drums and percussion.name: Spoons
Drums and percussion.notes: (also Lojki / Lozhki in Russian for wooden spoons) Spoons can be played as a makeshift percussion instrument. A pair of spoons is held with concave sides facing out and with a finger between their handles to space them apart. When the pair is struck, the spoons sharply hit each other and then spring back to their original position. The spoons are typically struck against the knee and the palm of the hand.

Drums and percussion.name: Stomp Box
Drums and percussion.notes: Simple percussion instrument consisting of a small box placed under the foot, which is tapped or stamped on rhythmically to produce a sound similar to that of a bass drum.

Drums and percussion.name: String Drum
Drums and percussion.notes: Also lion's roar: a drum head with a horsehair cord running through it. played by rubbing against the skin, which produces a sound similar to the roar of a lion.

Drums and percussion.name: Surdo
Drums and percussion.notes: A large bass drum used in many kinds of Brazilian music, most notably samba. Sizes normally vary between 8" or even 14" and 26" or even 29" diameter.

Drums and percussion.name: Surigane
Drums and percussion.notes: Japanese metal percussion instrument

Drums and percussion.name: T'rung
Drums and percussion.notes: Also t'rưng: a traditional bamboo xylophone used in Vietnam's Central Highlands.

Drums and percussion.name: Taal
Drums and percussion.notes: Also talam, mandira, manjira, manjeera, jalra, karatala, kartal or gini: a pair of high-pitched clash cymbals from the Indian subcontinent.

Drums and percussion.name: Taarija
Drums and percussion.notes: A Moroccan single-skin tube drum, related to the darbouka.

Drums and percussion.name: Tabl Baladi
Drums and percussion.notes: A large wood-framed drum from Egypt with heavy skin on both sides, used to provide the beat for dances and in religious ceremonies.

Drums and percussion.name: Tabla
Drums and percussion.notes: A popular Indian percussion instrument used in the classical, popular and religious music of the Indian subcontinent and in Hindustani classical music. The instrument consists of a pair of hand drums of contrasting sizes and timbres.

Drums and percussion.name: Taiko
Drums and percussion.notes: Generic Japanese word for 'drum'.

Drums and percussion.name: Talking Drum
Drums and percussion.notes: Also called Odondo, Dondo, Lunna, Donno, Kalangu, Doodo, Tama, Tamma, Dundun, Gangan - A West African drum whose pitch can be regulated to the extent that it is said the drum "talks". The player puts the drum under one shoulder and beats the instrument with a stick. A talking drum player raises or lowers the pitch by squeezing or releasing the drum's strings with the upper arm.

Drums and percussion.name: Tam-tam
Drums and percussion.notes: A flat faced gong

Drums and percussion.name: Tambora
Drums and percussion.notes: (from the Spanish word tambor, meaning "drum") is a name for a group of Afro-Caribbean musical instruments. It is used in many Latin American countries musical styles; in the Dominican musical folkloric styles and merengue, the Cumbia in Colombia, and the Venezuelan gaita.

Drums and percussion.name: Tamborim
Drums and percussion.notes: A small, round Brazilian frame drum of Portuguese and African origin. The frame is 6" in diameter and may be made of metal, plastic or wood. The head is typically made of nylon and is normally very tightly tuned in order to ensure a high, sharp sound and a minimum of sustain. The drum is devoid of snares or jingles.

Drums and percussion.name: Tan-Tan
Drums and percussion.notes: (also Tantan, Tan Tan) - a cylindrical hand drum from Brazil that is used in small samba and pagode ensembles. It imitates the big Surdo which is played by the famous samba baterias (percussion ensembles). But due to its smaller size the tan tan is not as loud as a Surdo and so it is played rarely in big samba schools.

Drums and percussion.name: Tap Dance
Drums and percussion.notes: The tapping sound made when the small metal plates on the dancer's shoes touch a hard floor. This lively, rhythmic tapping makes the performer not just a dancer, but also a percussive musician.

Drums and percussion.name: Tar (Drum)
Drums and percussion.notes: A single-headed frame drum from North Africa and the Middle East.

Drums and percussion.name: Tbal
Drums and percussion.notes: A large ceremonial double-goatskin drum struck with curved sticks, used mainly during gnawa rituals.

Drums and percussion.name: Temple Bells
Drums and percussion.notes: Also called: Japanese Temple Bells, Tibetan Bells

Drums and percussion.name: Temple Block
Drums and percussion.notes: A percussion instrument originating in China, Japan and Korea where it is used in religious ceremonies. It is a carved hollow wooden instrument with a large slit. In its traditional form, (the Wooden Fish )the shape is somewhat bulbous; modern instruments are also used which are rectangular in shape.

Drums and percussion.name: Thavil
Drums and percussion.notes: A barrel shaped percussion instrument from Tamil Nadu.

Drums and percussion.name: Thunder Sheet
Drums and percussion.notes: A thin sheet of metal used to produce sound effects for musical or dramatic events.

Drums and percussion.name: Tifa
Drums and percussion.notes: A single-headed goblet drum used throughout the Maluku Islands of Eastern Indonesia.

Drums and percussion.name: Timpani
Drums and percussion.notes: Also known as kettledrums.

Drums and percussion.name: Tingsha
Drums and percussion.notes: Also ting-sha: small paired cymbals used in prayer and rituals by Tibetan Buddhist practitioners

Drums and percussion.name: Tom Tom
Drums and percussion.notes: A cylindrical drum with no snare.

Drums and percussion.name: Tombak
Drums and percussion.notes: Also doumbek, dumbec, dumbek, dumbeg, dumbelek, tarambuke, tonbak, toumbeleki, toumperleki, tumbak, zerbaghali, zarb: a goblet drum from Iran, considered the principal percussion instrument of Persian music.

Drums and percussion.name: Toubeleki
Drums and percussion.notes: A traditional Greek goblet drum, usually made from metal with a single skin stretched over the top. It is used particularly in laiko and rebetiko music.

Drums and percussion.name: Tsuzumi
Drums and percussion.notes: Also tsudzumi, kotsuzumi (鼓): a small Japanese hand drum shaped like an hourglass, with two drum heads linked by cords that can be squeezed or released to alter the pitch of the drum while playing.

Drums and percussion.name: Tüngür
Drums and percussion.notes: While "kenggirge" is the term for "drum" (used in Lamaist temple ceremonies) in Tuvan, the term "tüngür" is used to refer to a shaman drum. Both are approximately two feet in diameter. Drums used by Tuvan shamans frequently have a skin on one side and a handle on the back; they are similar to sub-contrabass tambourines. They have small bells or jingles tied to their handle.

Drums and percussion.name: Udu
Drums and percussion.notes: A water jug with one more holes, usually made of clay

Drums and percussion.name: Vibraslap
Drums and percussion.notes: A percussion instrument consisting of a piece of stiff wire (bent in a handle-like shape) connecting a wood ball to a block of wood with metal "teeth" inside

Drums and percussion.name: Washboard
Drums and percussion.notes: The washboard and frottoir are used as a percussion instrument, employing the ribbed metal surface of the cleaning device as a rhythm instrument. It is played primarily by tapping and, but also scraping, the washboard with thimbles.

Drums and percussion.name: Waterphone
Drums and percussion.notes: A unique type of atonal acoustic musical instrument constructed largely of a stainless steel resonator "bowl" with a cylindrical "neck", containing a small amount of water, and with brass rods around the rim of the bowl. The waterphone produces a vibrant ethereal type of music.

Drums and percussion.name: Zabumba
Drums and percussion.notes: Brazilian percussion instrument

Tuned Percussion.name: Amadinda
Tuned Percussion.notes: A tuned log mallet instrument derivative of an Ugandan xylophone.

Tuned Percussion.name: Angklung
Tuned Percussion.notes: A musical instrument made out of two bamboo tubes attached to a bamboo frame. The tubes are carved so that they have a resonant pitch when struck. The two tubes are tuned to octaves. The base of the frame is held with one hand while the other hand shakes the instrument rapidly from side to side. This causes a rapidly repeating note to sound

Tuned Percussion.name: Balafon
Tuned Percussion.notes: (also Bala, Balaphone) - a resonated frame, wooden keyed percussion idiophone of West Africa; part of the idiophone family of tuned percussion instruments that includes the xylophone, marimba, glockenspiel, and the vibraphone. Sound is produced by striking the tuned keys with two padded sticks.

Tuned Percussion.name: Boomwhacker
Tuned Percussion.notes: Boomwhackers Tuned Percussion Tubes are lightweight, hollow, color-coded, plastic tubes, tuned to musical pitches by length.

Tuned Percussion.name: Carillon
Tuned Percussion.notes: At least 23 cup-shaped bells played from a baton keyboard using fists and feet (such an instrument with fewer than this number of bells is known as a chime). Carillon bells are made of bell bronze, approximately 78% copper and 22% tin, normally housed in bell towers. However, there are indoor carillons usually of light weight bells which may be hung inside shopping malls or in theatres

Tuned Percussion.name: Celesta
Tuned Percussion.notes: (also celeste} Operated by a keyboard, its appearance is similar to that of an upright piano (four- or five-octave) or of a large wooden music box (three-octave). The keys are connected to hammers which strike a graduated set of metal (usually steel) plates suspended over wooden resonators. One of the best-known works that makes use of the celesta is Tchaikovsky's "Dance of the Sugarplum Fairy" from The Nutcracker. The sound of the celesta is akin to that of the glockenspiel, but with a much softer and more subtle timbre. This quality gave rise to the instrument's name, celeste meaning "heavenly" in French.

Tuned Percussion.name: Chimes
Tuned Percussion.notes: An orchestral percussion instrument which is a set of about 18 metal tubes tuned chromatically and played with a hammer

Tuned Percussion.name: Crotales
Tuned Percussion.notes: (also antique cymbals) - Percussion instruments consisting of small, tuned bronze or brass disks. Each is about 4 inches in diameter with a flat top surface and a nipple on the base. They are commonly played by being struck with hard mallets. They may also be played by striking two disks together in the same manner as finger cymbals, or by bowing. Their sound is rather like a small tuned bell, only with a much brighter sound, and a much longer resonance.

Tuned Percussion.name: Guitaret
Tuned Percussion.notes: Electric lamellophone

Tuned Percussion.name: Hammered Dulcimer
Tuned Percussion.notes: A western European instrument with a trapezoidal soundboard, played by striking strings with small metal hammers. Known as the Hackbrett in German. Related instruments are the Santur (Iran), Santoor (India), Cimbalom (eastern Europe) and Yangqin (China).

Tuned Percussion.name: Jal Tarang
Tuned Percussion.notes: An Indian instrument consisting of a set of ceramic or metal bowls filled with water, played by striking the edge with stick.

Tuned Percussion.name: Kalimba
Tuned Percussion.notes: Also called Thumb Piano, Finger Harp, Mbira, Kissansi, Sansa. An African plucked idiophone.

Tuned Percussion.name: Marimbula
Tuned Percussion.notes: A lamellophone played by plucking metal keys attached to a resonator box

Tuned Percussion.name: Metallophone
Tuned Percussion.notes: Any musical instrument consisting of tuned metal bars which are struck to make sound, usually with a mallet.

Tuned Percussion.name: Musical Box
Tuned Percussion.notes: (also music box) is a 19th century automatic musical instrument that produces sounds by the use of a set of pins placed on a revolving cylinder or disc so as to strike the tuned teeth of a steel comb.

Tuned Percussion.name: Prempensua
Tuned Percussion.notes: Large lamellophone that is used to provide bass in the music of Ghana.

Tuned Percussion.name: Santoor
Tuned Percussion.notes: A 100-stringed trapezoid-shaped hammered dulcimer from India, often made of walnut and derived from the Persian Santur.

Tuned Percussion.name: Santur
Tuned Percussion.notes: A trapezoid-shaped hammered dulcimer from Iran/Persia, often made of walnut, with 72 strings. The special-shaped mallets (mezrab) are lightweight and are held between the index and middle fingers. For the related Indian instrument with 100 strings, see Santoor.

Tuned Percussion.name: Tubaphone
Tuned Percussion.notes: Type of metallophone constructed from a series of metal tubes arranged in a keyboard configuration.

Tuned Percussion.name: Tubular Bells
Tuned Percussion.notes: aka Orchestral Chimes

Tuned Percussion.name: Tun
Tuned Percussion.notes: Two-tongued wooden marimba fashioned from a block of wood

Tuned Percussion.name: Vibraphone
Tuned Percussion.notes: Also called 'Vibraharp' or shortened to 'Vibes' - in the mallet subfamily of the percussion family. It is similar in appearance to the xylophone and marimba, although the vibraphone uses aluminum bars instead of the wooden bars of those instruments. Also features tuned resonators below the bars, with motor driven discs that vary the amplitude, giving the distinctive wavering sound to the instrument.

Tuned Percussion.name: Xylorimba
Tuned Percussion.notes: Also xylo-marimba, marimba-xylophone: a tuned percussion instrument similar in shape to a xylophone but with an extended 5-octave range, typically an octave higher than that of the marimba. In spite of its name, it is not a combination of a xylophone and a marimba.

Keyboard.name: Baby Grand Piano
Keyboard.notes: A grand piano that may be shorter than it is wide.

Keyboard.name: Chamberlin
Keyboard.notes: (also Chamberlain) - an electro-mechanical keyboard instrument that was a precursor to the Mellotron.

Keyboard.name: Concert Grand Piano
Keyboard.notes: A grand piano that is between about 2.2 m to 3 m long.

Keyboard.name: Dulcitone
Keyboard.notes: A keyboard instrument in which sound is produced by a range of tuning forks, which vibrate when struck by felt-covered hammers activated by the keyboard.

Keyboard.name: Electric Piano
Keyboard.notes: For Rhodes and Wurlitzer electric pianos, and variations.

Keyboard.name: Fortepiano
Keyboard.notes: The fortepiano has leather-covered hammers and thin, harpsichord-like strings. It has a much lighter case construction than the modern piano and it has no metal frame or bracing. The action and hammers are lighter. The tone of the fortepiano is quite different from that of the modern piano, being softer with less sustain. Accents tend to stand out more than on the modern piano, as they differ from softer notes in timbre as well as volume, and decay rapidly.

Keyboard.name: Grand Piano
Keyboard.notes: Grand pianos have the frame and strings placed horizontally, with the strings extending away from the keyboard.

Keyboard.name: Harmonium
Keyboard.notes: Pedal or hand pumped keyboard reed instrument, common in Indian music styles.

Keyboard.name: Luthéal
Keyboard.notes: A hybrid instrument in which two treble and two bass stops are added to a grand piano to enable the production of additional timbres resembling cimbalom, harpsichord, and harp (or lute).

Keyboard.name: Mellotron
Keyboard.notes: An electromechanical polyphonic keyboard musical instrument, in effect the world's first sample-playback keyboard. Works by playing back a bank of magnetic tape strips, each tape with approximately eight seconds of playing time

Keyboard.name: Omnichord
Keyboard.notes: An electronic musical instrument manufactured by the Suzuki Musical Instrument Corporation. It typically features a touch plate and numerous chord buttons.

Keyboard.name: Ondes Martenot
Keyboard.notes: (also Ondium Martenot, Martenot and ondes musicales) is an early electronic musical instrument, invented in 1928 by Maurice Martenot and originally very similar in sound to the Theremin. The instrument is especially known for its eerie wavering notes produced by the thermionic valves that produce oscillating frequencies.

Keyboard.name: Organ
Keyboard.notes: For Hammond organ use Electric Organ [Hammond]

Keyboard.name: Parlour Grand Piano
Keyboard.notes: A grand piano that is about 1.7 m to 2.2 m.

Keyboard.name: Pedalboard
Keyboard.notes: A keyboard played with the feet

Keyboard.name: Player Piano
Keyboard.notes: A piano that records a performance using rolls of paper with perforations, and then replays the performance using pneumatic devices.

Keyboard.name: Portative Organ
Keyboard.notes: Also organetto: a very small pipe organ, smaller than the positive organ, that is played while held by or strapped to the performer.

Keyboard.name: Positive Organ
Keyboard.notes: A portable pipe organ, usually single-manual, common between the 10th and the 18th centuries, often used in basso continuo.

Keyboard.name: Pump Organ
Keyboard.notes: type of free-reed organ that generates sound as air flows past a vibrating piece of thin metal in a frame. Includes the reed organ, harmonium, and melodeon.

Keyboard.name: Regal
Keyboard.notes: A small late-medieval portable organ, furnished with beating reeds and having two bellows like a positive organ.

Keyboard.name: Samvadini
Keyboard.notes: An Indian instrument created by adding a swarmandal to the top of a harmonium.

Keyboard.name: Stylophone
Keyboard.notes: A miniature stylus-operated synthesizer.

Keyboard.name: Synth
Keyboard.notes: Shortened version of 'Synthesizer'.

Keyboard.name: Synth Bass
Keyboard.notes: A instrument to substitute for double bass, string bass, or electric bass. Unlike a guitar syntheszier, the synth bass is played via small keyboard, or sometimes via software.

Keyboard.name: Synthesizer
Keyboard.notes: (also Synthesiser, Synth) An electronic instrument capable of producing sounds by generating electrical signals of different frequencies. Synthesizers use a number of different technologies. Among the most popular waveform synthesis techniques are subtractive synthesis, additive synthesis, wavetable synthesis, frequency modulation synthesis, phase distortion synthesis, physical modeling synthesis and sample-based synthesis. Other sound synthesis methods, like subharmonic synthesis or granular synthesis, are not commonly found in hardware music synthesizers. Synthesizers are often controlled with a piano-style keyboard, leading such instruments to be referred to simply as "keyboards".

Keyboard.name: Tangent Piano
Keyboard.notes: Keyboard instrument that resembles a harpsichord and early pianos in design.

Keyboard.name: Upright Piano
Keyboard.notes: Upright pianos, also called vertical pianos, are more compact because the frame and strings are vertical, extending up and down from the keyboard and hammers.

Keyboard.name: Virginal
Keyboard.notes: Member of the harpsichord family. Unlike the harpsichord and spinet, the virginal’s single set of strings runs nearly parallel to the keyboard. By building the instrument with its keyboard at one side or the other of the front of the rectangular case, different tone colours can be obtained because of the change in plucking point of the string.

Stringed Instruments.name: 7-string Acoustic Guitar
Stringed Instruments.notes: Classical guitars with one extra (usually bass) string. See also Guitarra Séptima (Mexican), Semistrunnaya Gitara (Russian) and Violão de Sete Cordas (Brazillian) for specific types.

Stringed Instruments.name: 8-string Bass Guitar
Stringed Instruments.notes: Also octave bass: a bass guitar with paired strings tuned an octave apart, similar to a 12-string guitar.

Stringed Instruments.name: Acoustic Bass
Stringed Instruments.notes: A bass version of the acoustic guitar. Please use carefully, as this is also sometimes used as a synonym for the Double Bass

Stringed Instruments.name: Acoustic Guitar
Stringed Instruments.notes: (also Folk Guitar)- Has metal strings and a larger body than a classical guitar.

Stringed Instruments.name: Acoustic Piccolo Bass
Stringed Instruments.notes: An adaptation of the double bass for higher tunings.

Stringed Instruments.name: Adungu
Stringed Instruments.notes: Also a'dungu, ekidongo or ennenga: an arched harp from northwestern Uganda, usually with between seven and ten strings.

Stringed Instruments.name: Ajaeng
Stringed Instruments.notes: A wide bowed zither from Korea with strings of twisted silk that takes the bass part in ensemble music.

Stringed Instruments.name: Angélique
Stringed Instruments.notes: Also angelica: A plucked string instrument of the Baroque era that combines features of the lute, the harp, and the theorbo.

Stringed Instruments.name: Archlute
Stringed Instruments.notes: A plucked string instrument developed around 1600, it is essentially a tenor lute with a neck extension similar to that of the theorbo. Eventually eclipsed the theorbo in continuo roles in Baroque music.

Stringed Instruments.name: Arco Bass
Stringed Instruments.notes: An acoustic bass guitar redesigned to be played upright.

Stringed Instruments.name: Arpa
Stringed Instruments.notes: A native instrument from Paraguay (South America). Unlike "Harp", this doesn't have pedals. Called also "Arpa Paraguaya" or "Arpa Criolla". Also used in folkloric music of Venezuela and Honduras. Today, Japanese artists play it in experimental music.

Stringed Instruments.name: Autoharp
Stringed Instruments.notes: A zither-like musical string instrument having a series of chord bars attached to dampers which, when depressed, mute all the strings other than those that form the desired chord

Stringed Instruments.name: Baglama
Stringed Instruments.notes: A member of the long-necked lute family, used by various cultures in the Eastern Mediterranean. Also called a Saz.

Stringed Instruments.name: Bajo Quinto
Stringed Instruments.notes: A five course version of the bajo sexto

Stringed Instruments.name: Bajo Sexto
Stringed Instruments.notes: A type of 12 string guitar, fused with a bass, used in Mexican music

Stringed Instruments.name: Bandolin
Stringed Instruments.notes: A smaller variation of the mandolin from Trinidad.

Stringed Instruments.name: Bandora
Stringed Instruments.notes: Also bandore: a large long-necked plucked string-instrument that can be regarded as a bass cittern, similar to the smaller orpharion.

Stringed Instruments.name: Bandura
Stringed Instruments.notes: A Ukrainian plucked string instrument similar to a zither.

Stringed Instruments.name: Bandurria
Stringed Instruments.notes: A plectrum plucked chordophone from Spain, similar to the cittern and the mandolin, primarily used in Spanish folk music.

Stringed Instruments.name: Banhu
Stringed Instruments.notes: A Chinese traditional bowed string instrument in the huqin family of instruments. It is used primarily in northern China. Ban means a piece of wood and hu is short for huqin. Like the erhu and gaohu, the banhu has two strings, is held vertically, and the bow hair passes in between the two strings. The banhu differs in construction from the erhu in that its soundbox is generally made from a coconut shell rather than wood, and instead of a snakeskin that is commonly used to cover the faces of huqin instruments, the banhu uses a thin wooden board.

Stringed Instruments.name: Baritone Guitar
Stringed Instruments.notes: A variation on the standard guitar, with a longer scale length that allows it to be tuned to a lower range.

Stringed Instruments.name: Baroque Guitar
Stringed Instruments.notes: String instrument with five courses of gut strings and moveable gut frets.

Stringed Instruments.name: Bass Guitar
Stringed Instruments.notes: Another method of crediting this popular instrument, instead of having to use 'Bass [Bass Guitar]. Either method is acceptable.

Stringed Instruments.name: Bass Violin
Stringed Instruments.notes: Baroque-era bass instruments of the violin family, somewhat larger than the modern cello, but usually tuned to the same pitch and often used as a continuo instrument. Note: sometimes the modern double bass is referred to as a 'bass violin' or 'bass fiddle'; in such a case, please use Double Bass.

Stringed Instruments.name: Berimbau
Stringed Instruments.notes: Single-string instrument, a musical bow, from Brazil

Stringed Instruments.name: Bhapang
Stringed Instruments.notes: A drum with a string in the centre, that is played by plucking the string and varying the tension on the string.

Stringed Instruments.name: Biwa
Stringed Instruments.notes: A Japanese short-necked fretted lute, and a close variant of the Chinese pipa.

Stringed Instruments.name: Blaster Beam
Stringed Instruments.notes: Also called just 'Beam'

Stringed Instruments.name: Bolon
Stringed Instruments.notes: 3-string instrument which is plucked and struck by hand, producing deep bass sounds

Stringed Instruments.name: Bulbul Tarang
Stringed Instruments.notes: A small music box like a combination of a typewriter, a mandolin and a dulcimer. 5 metal strings (usually all tuned the same) run over a square wooden box. The keys (usually keys from an old typewriter) press their arm onto the strings like it is a fret, shortening the strings to the appropriate note.

Stringed Instruments.name: Buzuq
Stringed Instruments.notes: lso bozuq, bouzouk, buzuk: a long-necked fretted lute associated with the music of Lebanon and Syria, related to the Greek bouzouki and Turkish saz.

Stringed Instruments.name: Byzaanchi
Stringed Instruments.notes: Chinese long necked instrument

Stringed Instruments.name: Cavaquinho
Stringed Instruments.notes: Brazilian predecessor to the ukulele

Stringed Instruments.name: Cello
Stringed Instruments.notes: Short name for violoncello

Stringed Instruments.name: Celtic Harp
Stringed Instruments.notes: Also cláirseach (Irish), clàrsach (Scottish Gaelic), telyn (Welsh), telenn (Breton): a triangular-frame harp traditional to the Celtic nations of northwest Europe.

Stringed Instruments.name: Cetara
Stringed Instruments.notes: Also cetara: a plucked string instrument from Corsica with sixteen or eighteen metal strings in paired courses, with mandolin-like body but larger.

Stringed Instruments.name: Changi
Stringed Instruments.notes: Georgian traditional instrument

Stringed Instruments.name: Chanzy
Stringed Instruments.notes: Sometimes spelled "tschansy", a lute with three strings

Stringed Instruments.name: Charango
Stringed Instruments.notes: A small South American stringed instrument of the lute family, about 66 cm long, traditionally made with the shell of the back of an armadillo

Stringed Instruments.name: Chitarra Battente
Stringed Instruments.notes: A guitar with doubled metal strings (typically in five courses, sometimes four), used to strum the rhythm in the folk music of southern Italy.

Stringed Instruments.name: Chitarrone
Stringed Instruments.notes: A plucked string instrument.

Stringed Instruments.name: Chonguri
Stringed Instruments.notes: Gregorian plucked string instrument

Stringed Instruments.name: Cigar Box Guitar
Stringed Instruments.notes: A simple guitar, usually with three strings and an empty cigar box as a resonator.

Stringed Instruments.name: Cimbalom
Stringed Instruments.notes: Also cymbalum, cymbalom, tambal, tsymbaly, tsimbl or santouri, a musical instrument found mainly in the music of Hungary, Romania, Moldova, Greece and Ukraine. In Czechoslovakia it was also known as a Cimbal. It is related to the hammered dulcimer of Western Europe.

Stringed Instruments.name: Citole
Stringed Instruments.notes: Ancestor of the Cittern

Stringed Instruments.name: Cittern
Stringed Instruments.notes: A stringed instrument of the guitar family dating from the Renaissance. The name "cittern" has also been applied in the late twentieth century to a number of variant members of the mandolin family.

Stringed Instruments.name: Classical Guitar
Stringed Instruments.notes: (also Spanish guitar, Nylon String Guitar) 6-stringed plucked string instrument.

Stringed Instruments.name: Clavichord
Stringed Instruments.notes: A stringed keyboard instrument known from the late Medieval, through the Renaissance, Baroque and Classical eras. The clavichord produces sound by striking brass or iron strings with small metal blades called tangents. Vibrations are transmitted through the bridge(s) to the soundboard.

Stringed Instruments.name: Clavinet
Stringed Instruments.notes: An electrophonic keyboard instrument manufactured by the Hohner company. It is essentially an electronically amplified clavichord, analogous to an electric guitar. Its distinctive bright staccato sound has appeared particularly in funk, disco, rock, and reggae songs. Not to be confused with clarinet!

Stringed Instruments.name: Cobza
Stringed Instruments.notes: (also Koboz) A Romanian and Moldovan folk instrument of the lute family.

Stringed Instruments.name: Contrabass
Stringed Instruments.notes: Also called 'Double Bass'.

Stringed Instruments.name: Crwth
Stringed Instruments.notes: Also crowd or rote: a Welsh bowed lyre.

Stringed Instruments.name: Cuatro
Stringed Instruments.notes: Any of several Latin American instruments of the guitar or lute family. The cuatro is smaller in size than a guitar. Cuatro means four in Spanish, although the current instruments may have more than four strings.

Stringed Instruments.name: Cümbüş
Stringed Instruments.notes: (also Cumbus) a Turkish stringed instrument of relatively modern origin. Developed in the early 20th century by Zeynelabidin Cümbüş as an oud-like instrument that could be heard as part of a larger ensemble. In construction it resembles both the American banjo and the Middle Eastern oud.

Stringed Instruments.name: Deaejeng
Stringed Instruments.notes: A long zither with 15 strings, slightly larger than the gayageum

Stringed Instruments.name: Diddley Bow
Stringed Instruments.notes: Single-stringed American instrument

Stringed Instruments.name: Dilruba
Stringed Instruments.notes: A cross between the sitar and sarangi. It is extremely close to the esraj and the mayuri vina. It so close that most people are unable to tell them apart. The difference is to be found in the shape of the resonators and the manner in which the sympathetic strings attach. Still they are so similar that a dilruba player has no trouble playing an esraj or a mayuri vina and vice versa.

Stringed Instruments.name: Dobro
Stringed Instruments.notes: (also Resonator Guitar)

Stringed Instruments.name: Dojo
Stringed Instruments.notes: Stringed Instrument

Stringed Instruments.name: Dombra
Stringed Instruments.notes: (also dombıra, dambura, dumbıra, tumpıra, tumra..) Long-necked relative of the Lute

Stringed Instruments.name: Domra
Stringed Instruments.notes: (Ukrainian: домра) - A long-necked Ukrainian string instrument of the lute family with a round body and three or four metal strings.

Stringed Instruments.name: Doshpuluur
Stringed Instruments.notes: Long-necked Tuvan lute made from wood.

Stringed Instruments.name: Dotara
Stringed Instruments.notes: Also dotar: an instrument from Bengal with two, four or five strings that are plucked. Note: not to be confused with the dutar of Iran and Central Asia.

Stringed Instruments.name: Double Bass
Stringed Instruments.notes: Also called: Bass Fiddle, Contrabass, Upright Bass, String Bass, Standup Bass, Acoustic Bass (careful with this, as there are sit-down acoustic basses as well), Bass Viol, Contrabass Viol, Bass Violin, Doghouse Bass, Dog-House, Bull Fiddle, Hoss Bass, Bunkhouse Bass

Stringed Instruments.name: Dulcimer
Stringed Instruments.notes: Please use this role only if the type of dulcimer cannot be determined. See Hammered Dulcimer, Mountain Dulcimer (Appalachian), Santur (Iran), Santoor (India), Cimbalom (eastern Europe) and Yangqin (China).

Stringed Instruments.name: Dutar
Stringed Instruments.notes: (also dotar, doutar, Persian دو تار , Uzbek dutor) is a traditional long-necked two-stringed lute found in Central Asia and South Asia. (Note: not to be confused with the dotara of Bengal.)

Stringed Instruments.name: Đàn bầu
Stringed Instruments.notes: A Vietnamese monochord.

Stringed Instruments.name: Đàn Nguyệt
Stringed Instruments.notes: A two-stringed Vietnamese traditional instrument with a long neck and a round body.

Stringed Instruments.name: Đàn Tranh
Stringed Instruments.notes: Also đàn thập lục: a plucked zither from Vietnam with a long soundbox with steel strings and movable bridges, derived from the Chinese guzheng.

Stringed Instruments.name: Đàn Tỳ Bà
Stringed Instruments.notes: A traditional Vietnamese plucked string instrument derived from the Chinese pipa.

Stringed Instruments.name: Ektare
Stringed Instruments.notes: From Nepal, consists of one string tied to a small drum with two flexible supports stretching the string to the 'head' of the instrument, which is constructed as a smaller version of the drum body. Played by plucking the string or playing the drum with the hand, the note can be altered by bending the supports, or by holding the string.

Stringed Instruments.name: Electric Bass
Stringed Instruments.notes: Also just 'Bass'

Stringed Instruments.name: Electric Guitar
Stringed Instruments.notes: See also Guitar and Acoustic Guitar

Stringed Instruments.name: Electric Harp
Stringed Instruments.notes: An electric version of the acoustic harp that has a solid body and is amplified electronically rather than acoustically.

Stringed Instruments.name: Electric Sitar
Stringed Instruments.notes: A type of electric guitar designed to mimic the sound of the Indian sitar.

Stringed Instruments.name: Electric Upright Bass
Stringed Instruments.notes: (also EUB, Stick Bass, Baby Bass) - An electronically amplified version of the double bass that has a smaller or non-existent body, which greatly reduces the size and weight of the instrument, as well as enhances the feedback resistance of the amplified instrument. The EUB retains enough of the features of the double bass so that double bass players are comfortable performing on it. While the EUB retains some of the tonal characteristics of the double bass, its electrically-amplified nature also gives it its own unique sound. Although invented in the 1930s, it wasn't really until the introduction in the late 1950s of the Ampeg Baby Bass that the concept took off.

Stringed Instruments.name: Epinette des Vosges
Stringed Instruments.notes: Traditional plucked-string instrument of the zither family, whose use was confined to two areas in the Vosges mountains of France.

Stringed Instruments.name: Erhu
Stringed Instruments.notes: (also 二胡, èrhú, nanhu 南胡, southern fiddle, Chinese violin, Chinese two-string fiddle) - A two-stringed bowed musical instrument, used as a solo instrument as well as in small ensembles and large orchestras. It is the most popular instrument in the huqin (胡琴) family of Chinese bowed string instruments.

Stringed Instruments.name: Esraj
Stringed Instruments.notes: (also এস্রাজ, इसराज, israja) A string instrument found in the east and central areas of India, particularly Bengal, as well as Bangladesh, and it is used in a somewhat wider variety of musical styles than is the dilruba.

Stringed Instruments.name: Fiddle
Stringed Instruments.notes: A violin, often used in folk music. One very slight difference between "fiddles" and ordinary violins may be seen in American (e.g., bluegrass and old-time music) fiddling: in these styles, the top of the bridge may be cut so that it is very slightly less curved. This reduces the range of right-arm motion required for the rapid string-crossings found in some styles, and is said to make it easier to play double stops and shuffles (bariolage), or to make triple stops possible, allowing one to play chords.

Stringed Instruments.name: Fidel Płocka
Stringed Instruments.notes: An obsolete string instrument from medieval Poland, with a body similar to a modern violin but with a short and very wide neck. It was played upright resting on the knee, similar to the treble viol.

Stringed Instruments.name: Five-String Viola
Stringed Instruments.notes: A viola with an extra string, usually tuned to high E.

Stringed Instruments.name: Five-String Violin
Stringed Instruments.notes: A violin with an extra string, usually tuned to lower C.

Stringed Instruments.name: Flamenco Guitar
Stringed Instruments.notes: Built lighter in weight than classical guitars, which produces a “brighter” and more percussive sound quality. Volume has traditionally been very important for flamenco guitarists, as they must be heard over the sound of the dancers’ nailed shoes. In contrast to the classical guitar, the flamenco is often equipped with a tap plate (a golpeador), commonly made of plastic, similar to a pick guard, whose function is to protect the body of the guitar from the rhythmic finger taps, or golpes.

Stringed Instruments.name: Gadulka
Stringed Instruments.notes: (also gǎdulka, gudulka, g'dulka) A traditional Bulgarian bowed string instrument.

Stringed Instruments.name: Gaohu
Stringed Instruments.notes: (also 高胡, pgāohú, yuehu, 粤胡) is a Chinese bowed string instrument developed from the erhu in the 1920s. It belongs to the huqin family of instruments, together with the zhonghu, erhu, banhu, jinghu, and sihu, its name means "high pitched huqin". It has two strings and its soundbox is covered on the front (playing) end with snakeskin (from a python).

Stringed Instruments.name: Gayageum
Stringed Instruments.notes: (also spelled kayagûm) - A traditional Korean zither-like string instrument, with 12 strings, although more recently variants have been constructed with 21 or other numbers of strings

Stringed Instruments.name: Geomungo
Stringed Instruments.notes: (also spelled komungo, Komunko, or kŏmungo) is a traditional Korean stringed musical instrument of zither family instrument with both bridges and frets.

Stringed Instruments.name: Ghaychak
Stringed Instruments.notes: Also gheychak: a double-chambered bowed lute with four or more metal strings and a short fretless neck used in the region around Iran. Not to be confused with the dissimilar ghijak of Central Asia.

Stringed Instruments.name: Ghijak
Stringed Instruments.notes: Also ghidjak, ghichak, gidzhak, gijak, g'ijjak, or ghijek, aijieke or jizihake: a group of related spike fiddles from central Asia. Not to be confused with the dissimilar Persian kamancheh.

Stringed Instruments.name: Giga
Stringed Instruments.notes: Also vihuela de arco, viola d'arco: a bowed stringed instrument that originated during the medieval period in the Iberian peninsula. It is regarded as one of the ancestors of the viola da gamba.

Stringed Instruments.name: Gottuvâdyam
Stringed Instruments.notes: (also gottuvadyam, chitravina, chitra vina, or mahanataka vina, கோடடு வாத்தியம்) A Carnatic music string instrument played mainly in South India. It is usually used as a solo instrument in Carnatic music.

Stringed Instruments.name: Gravikord
Stringed Instruments.notes: A 24-string electric double bridge-harp, based on the West African kora.

Stringed Instruments.name: Guimbri
Stringed Instruments.notes: A North African lute related to the sintir.

Stringed Instruments.name: Guitalele
Stringed Instruments.notes: (also guitarlele) A guitar-ukulele hybrid.

Stringed Instruments.name: Guitarra Séptima
Stringed Instruments.notes: A Mexican acoustic guitar with 14 strings in seven pairs.

Stringed Instruments.name: Guitarrón
Stringed Instruments.notes: (literally "large guitar" in Spanish) A very large, deep-bodied Mexican 6-string acoustic bass played in mariachi bands.

Stringed Instruments.name: GuitarViol
Stringed Instruments.notes: (also Bowed Guitar) - a guitar-formatted bowed string instrument.

Stringed Instruments.name: Guqin
Stringed Instruments.notes: (also 古琴, gǔqín, ku-ch'in) - The modern name for a plucked seven-string Chinese musical instrument of the zither family.

Stringed Instruments.name: Gusle
Stringed Instruments.notes: A single-stringed musical instrument traditional to the Dinarides region of the Balkans, held vertically between the knees. Note: not to be confused with the multi-stringed Gusli.

Stringed Instruments.name: Gusli
Stringed Instruments.notes: An ancient generic Slavic term for a stringed musical instrument.
