The term and its derivatives is used for either a plucked psaltery or zither-like instrument or for the violin or bowed equivalents. Originally the instrument had gut strings made from pig entrails. In recent times concert versions of the instrument have steel strings.

Stringed Instruments.name: Guzheng
Stringed Instruments.notes: (also gu zheng, gu-zheng, 古箏, gǔzhēng) A Chinese musical instrument that belongs to the zither family of string instruments.

Stringed Instruments.name: Haegum
Stringed Instruments.notes: A vertical fiddle with two strings.

Stringed Instruments.name: Halldorophone
Stringed Instruments.notes: An electro-acoustic instrument is loosely based on a cello and allows the player to color the sound of what is being played by feeding the vibrations of each string back into the body of the instrument.

Stringed Instruments.name: Hardingfele
Stringed Instruments.notes: A Hardanger fiddle or hardingfele (Norwegian) is a traditional stringed instrument from Norway. In modern designs, the instruments are very similar to the violin, but typically with thinner wood. The instrument typically has eight or nine strings; four are played like a violin, while the rest (aptly named sympathetic strings) resonate under the influence of the other four.

Stringed Instruments.name: Harp Guitar
Stringed Instruments.notes: A guitar with any number of additional unstopped strings that can accommodate individual plucking.

Stringed Instruments.name: Hualaycho
Stringed Instruments.notes: Also walaychu, maulincho: the smallest member of the charango family.

Stringed Instruments.name: Huapanguera
Stringed Instruments.notes: Also guitarra quinta huapanguera or guitarra huapanguera: a Mexican guitar-like instrument with a large resonating body with a short neck with 8 to 10 frets, that usually takes the bass part in a conjunto huasteco ensemble, along with the jarana huasteca and violin.

Stringed Instruments.name: Hummel
Stringed Instruments.notes: An old Swedish stringed instrument similar to an older type of zither and is related to the Norwegian langeleik.

Stringed Instruments.name: Huqin
Stringed Instruments.notes: A family of bowed string instruments used in Chinese music. The most common huqin are the erhu (essentially a Chinese violin, also spelt Urhu), zhonghu (Chinese viola), and gaohu (a higher pitched instrument commonly used in Cantonese music.) Over thirty types of huqin instruments have been documented.

Stringed Instruments.name: Hurdy Gurdy
Stringed Instruments.notes: On this instrument, several strings arranged so that they can be played simultaneously by a rotating wheel covered with rosin. It is essentially a mechanical violin.

Stringed Instruments.name: Ichigenkin
Stringed Instruments.notes: Also sumagoto: a Japanese single-stringed plucked zither with a slender, slightly curved body.

Stringed Instruments.name: Igil
Stringed Instruments.notes: Two-stringed Tuvan musical instrument, played by bowing the strings. The strings, and those of the bow, are traditionally made of hair from a horse's tail (strung parallel), but may also be made of nylon.

Stringed Instruments.name: Inānga
Stringed Instruments.notes: Also ikivuvu, indimbagazo: a trough zither of central Africa.

Stringed Instruments.name: Irish Bouzouki
Stringed Instruments.notes: An adaptation of the Greek 4-course bouzouki for Irish traditional music.

Stringed Instruments.name: Jarana
Stringed Instruments.notes: A guitar-shaped fretted stringed instrument from Mexico

Stringed Instruments.name: Jinghu
Stringed Instruments.notes: A Chinese bowed string instrument in the huqin family, used primarily in Beijing opera. It is the smallest and highest pitched instrument in the huqin family.

Stringed Instruments.name: Jouhikko
Stringed Instruments.notes: (also Jouhikannel) An ancient Finnish instrument, a type of bowed lyre, consisting of 2-4 strings. Its strings are traditionally of horsehair, though some modern instruments are made with carbon fibre, nylon, gut or metal viola strings.

Stringed Instruments.name: Kabosy
Stringed Instruments.notes: A box-shaped wooden guitar commonly played in music of Madagascar. It has four to six strings and is commonly thought to be a direct descendant of the Arabic lute. Known to locals as a 'mandoliny', also spelt kabossy

Stringed Instruments.name: Kamancha
Stringed Instruments.notes: folk fiddle of Rajasthan, is a rounded bowed instrument. It is also known as the Armenian spiked fiddle.

Stringed Instruments.name: Kannel
Stringed Instruments.notes: A type of Baltic psaltery (box zither) from Estonia.

Stringed Instruments.name: Kantele
Stringed Instruments.notes: A traditional plucked string instrument of the zither family. It is related to the Russian gusli, the Latvian kokle and the Lithuanian kanklės. Together these instruments make up the family known as Baltic Psalteries.

Stringed Instruments.name: Kanun
Stringed Instruments.notes: (also Qanun, քանոն, K’anon, قانون , Qānūn, قوانين , Qawānīn, κανονάκι, κανονακια, قانون , Qānūn, Kanun, Qanún, Kanun) - A string instrument found in the 10th century in Farab in Turkestan.

Stringed Instruments.name: Kemenche
Stringed Instruments.notes: Kemenche – (Kurdish: kemençe, Turkish: kemençe, Laz: Ç'ilili Greek: κεμεντζές) is a bottle-shaped, 3-stringed type of rebec or fiddle from the Black Sea region of Asia Minor also known as the "kementche of Laz" in Turkey. In Greece and the Pontian Greek diaspora, it is known as the "Pontian lyra" or "Politiki lyra". It is the main instrument used in Pontian music. The Macedonian/south Serbian version of the instrument is known as the kemane. The kemenche is played in the upright position, either by resting it on the knee when sitting, or held in front of the player when standing.

Stringed Instruments.name: Kirar
Stringed Instruments.notes: Lyre from Ethopia, played acoustic in traditional styles, but also amplified.

Stringed Instruments.name: Kobyz
Stringed Instruments.notes: (also Kazakh: қобыз, Kyl-Kobyz) - An ancient Kazakh string instrument. It has two strings made of horsehair. The resonating cavity is usually covered with goat leather.

Stringed Instruments.name: Kokle
Stringed Instruments.notes: A type of Baltic psaltery (box zither) from Latvia.

Stringed Instruments.name: Kokyu
Stringed Instruments.notes: (also kokyū) - A traditional Japanese string instrument, the only one played with a bow.

Stringed Instruments.name: Komuz
Stringed Instruments.notes: (комуз) – Also qomuz, qopuz, kopuz: an ancient Kyrgyz fretless long-necked lute, related to the Mongolian tovshuur. Not to be confused with the similarly named kobyz of Kazakhstan, cobza (cobuz, koboz) of eastern Europe or the kobza of Ukraine.

Stringed Instruments.name: Konghou
Stringed Instruments.notes: Also shu-konghou: a Chinese harp with paired strings on opposite sides of the instrument to enable techniques such as vibrato and bending tones.

Stringed Instruments.name: Kora
Stringed Instruments.notes: A 21 string harp-lute used extensively by Mandingo peoples in West Africa.

Stringed Instruments.name: Koto
Stringed Instruments.notes: Traditional stringed musical instrument from Japan resembling a zither.

Stringed Instruments.name: Krar
Stringed Instruments.notes: five or six-stringed bowl-shaped lyre from Ethiopia

Stringed Instruments.name: Langspil
Stringed Instruments.notes: A traditional Icelandic drone zither with a single melody string and usually 2 drone strings.

Stringed Instruments.name: Laouto
Stringed Instruments.notes: A long-necked lute similar to the oud.

Stringed Instruments.name: Lap Steel Guitar
Stringed Instruments.notes: A type of steel guitar, an instrument derived from and similar to the guitar, in which the strings are raised at both the nut and bridge ends of the fingerboard, typically to about half an inch. This makes the frets unusable, and they may be replaced by markers on some guitars. The player changes pitch by pressing a metal or glass bar against the strings instead of by pressing strings against the fingerboard.

Stringed Instruments.name: Laúd
Stringed Instruments.notes: (also Laud) - Belongs to the cittern family of instruments. Although "laúd" translates as "lute" in Spanish, it is a different instrument than the lute. A plectrum plucked chordophone from Spain, it consists of twelve metallic strings (six double), as the bandurria, but the neck is longer than a bandurria. Traditionally it forms part of serenaders or folk string musical groups, together with the guitar and the bandurria.

Stringed Instruments.name: Liuqin
Stringed Instruments.notes: (also 柳琴; pinyin: liǔq­ín) is a four-stringed Chinese mandolin with a pear-shaped body. It is small in size, almost a miniature copy of another Chinese plucked instrument, the pipa. But the range of its voice is much higher than the pipa.

Stringed Instruments.name: Lute Guitar
Stringed Instruments.notes: Also German lute, lotar, lutar or gittar: an instrument common in Germany from around 1850 with a body like a lute and usually six strings, although there are variants with up to 11 strings.

Stringed Instruments.name: Lyra Viol
Stringed Instruments.notes: Lyra Viol – A small bass viol often used as a solo instrument.

Stringed Instruments.name: Lyre
Stringed Instruments.notes: A stringed musical instrument well known for its use in Classical Antiquity. The recitations of the Ancient Greeks were accompanied by lyre playing. The lyre is a member of the zither family, and was ordinarily played by strumming with a plectrum, like a guitar, rather than being plucked, like a harp.

Stringed Instruments.name: Mandocello
Stringed Instruments.notes: (Mandoloncello, Liuto cantabile, Liuto moderno) - a plucked string instrument of the mandolin family. It has eight strings in four paired courses, tuned in 5ths like a mandolin, but is larger, and tuned CC-GG-dd-aa (low to high in pitch). It is to the mandolin what the cello is to the violin.

Stringed Instruments.name: Mandoguitar
Stringed Instruments.notes: A hybrid musical instrument that allows you to play mandolin music, sounding more or less like a mandolin, while playing the left-hand fingerings like a guitar. It has 6 single or double strings tuned to allow guitar-style fingerings and that it can be played in the tonal range of a standard mandolin.

Stringed Instruments.name: Mandola
Stringed Instruments.notes: (also tenor mandola) A fretted stringed musical instrument with the same relationship to the mandolin as the viola to the violin.

Stringed Instruments.name: Mandole
Stringed Instruments.notes: Also mandol, mondol: a steel-strung fretted instrument resembling an elongated mandolin, widely used in Algerian music.

Stringed Instruments.name: Mandolincello
Stringed Instruments.notes: A plucked string instrument of the mandolin family. It has eight strings in four paired courses, tuned in fifths like a mandolin, but is larger.

Stringed Instruments.name: Marxophone
Stringed Instruments.notes: A fretless zither played via a system of metal hammers.

Stringed Instruments.name: Masinko
Stringed Instruments.notes: Traditional Ethiopian instrument, one stringed, bowed lute.

Stringed Instruments.name: Misolo Guitar
Stringed Instruments.notes: A part between lead guitar and rhythm guitar used in some Congolese music.

Stringed Instruments.name: Mohan Veena
Stringed Instruments.notes: A name used for two distinct instruments used in Indian classical music. The most popular is a modified archtop Hawaiian guitar with between 19 and 21 strings in total that is played like a lap steel guitar. The other, older instrument is a hybrid of the instruments Sarod, Veena and Surbahar.

Stringed Instruments.name: Monochord
Stringed Instruments.notes: An ancient musical and scientific laboratory instrument. The word "monochord" comes from the Greek and means literally "one string." A misconception of the term lies within its name. Often a monochord has more than one string, most of the time two, one open string and a second string with a movable bridge. In a basic monochord, a single string is stretched over a sound box.

Stringed Instruments.name: Morinhoor
Stringed Instruments.notes: Also spelt as Morinhuur, A Horse-headed Mongolian Cello.

Stringed Instruments.name: Mountain Dulcimer
Stringed Instruments.notes: Also known as the Appalachian Dulcimer.

Stringed Instruments.name: Musical Bow
Stringed Instruments.notes: A simple string musical instrument consisting of a string supported by a flexible string bearer, usually made out of wood. Often, it is a normal archery bow used for music rather than as a weapon.

Stringed Instruments.name: N'vike
Stringed Instruments.notes: Also novike, n'vique, nobike: an instrument native to the Toba people of the Gran Chaco of South America with a neck made from a pickaxe handle, a resonator made from a tin box and a single string played with a horsehair bow.

Stringed Instruments.name: Nigenkin
Stringed Instruments.notes: A Japanese two-stringed plucked zither similar to the single-stringed ichigenkin.

Stringed Instruments.name: Nyckelharpa
Stringed Instruments.notes: (also Keyed Fiddle) - A traditional Swedish musical instrument. It is a string instrument or chordophone. Its keys are attached to tangents which, when a key is depressed, serve as frets to change the pitch of the string.

Stringed Instruments.name: Octave Violin
Stringed Instruments.notes: Also baritone violin, octave fiddle: a standard-sized violin body, often with some modifications, tuned an octave lower than the standard violin range and commonly used in Nordic folk music. Do not confuse with the tenor violin, an earlier instrument with the same range but a larger body.

Stringed Instruments.name: Octavina
Stringed Instruments.notes: A guitar-shaped instrument with a tuning similar to the laúd, originally Spanish, now used mostly in the Philippines.

Stringed Instruments.name: Octophone
Stringed Instruments.notes: An instrument related to the mandola that resembles an octave mandolin.

Stringed Instruments.name: Organistrum
Stringed Instruments.notes: The precursor to the hurdy-gurdy, invented in the 10th or 11th centuries and played by two individuals: one to turn the crank while the other operated the keys.

Stringed Instruments.name: Orpharion
Stringed Instruments.notes: A Renaissance instrument in the cittern family, similar to the larger bandora.

Stringed Instruments.name: Oud
Stringed Instruments.notes: Small, pear-shaped, stringed musical instrument, used in traditional Middle Eastern music.

Stringed Instruments.name: Outi
Stringed Instruments.notes: A post-Baroque instrument similar to a lute

Stringed Instruments.name: Pedal Harp
Stringed Instruments.notes: Also concert harp: a large, 47-string harp used in Western classical music among other forms.

Stringed Instruments.name: Pedal Steel Guitar
Stringed Instruments.notes: A type of electric guitar that uses a metal slide to stop the strings, rather than fingers on strings as with a conventional guitar. The pedal steel is placed horizontally on a stand, with the strings facing up towards the player, and is typically plucked with fingerpicks. The instrument's pedals are used to change the pitch of its strings while being played; the action of the pedals may either be fixed, or may be configurable by the player to select which strings are affected by the pedals. The pedal steel, with its smooth portamenti, bending chords and complex riffs, is one of the most recognizable and characteristic instruments of American country music.

Stringed Instruments.name: Piccolo Bass Guitar
Stringed Instruments.notes: An adaptation of the electric bass guitar for higher tunings.

Stringed Instruments.name: Pipa
Stringed Instruments.notes: (also pípá) - A plucked Chinese string instrument. Sometimes called the Chinese lute, the instrument has a pear-shaped wooden body.

Stringed Instruments.name: Portuguese Guitar
Stringed Instruments.notes: (also Portuguese Guitarra, Guitarra Portuguesa) - a plucked string instrument with twelve steel strings, strung in six courses comprising two strings each. It is one of the few musical instruments to use Preston tuners.[clarification needed] It is most notably associated with fado.

Stringed Instruments.name: Psalmodicon
Stringed Instruments.notes: (also Psalmodikon) - a single-stringed musical instrument. It was developed in Scandinavia for simplifying music in churches and schools.

Stringed Instruments.name: Psaltery
Stringed Instruments.notes: A stringed musical instrument of the harp or the zither family.

Stringed Instruments.name: Rabab
Stringed Instruments.notes: (not to be confused with Rebab) - The best known of all Afghan musical instruments. The rabab has a deep, waisted body, and the entire instrument is carved out of a single piece of mulberry wood. Its neck and upper body are hollow, covered with a thin piece of wood, and a membrane covers the lower body. It has three main playing strings tuned a fourth apart along with 12 to 15 wire sympathetic strings.

Stringed Instruments.name: Rabeca
Stringed Instruments.notes: Fiddle from northeastern Brazil and northern Portugal

Stringed Instruments.name: Rabel
Stringed Instruments.notes: Also arrabel, robel, rovel. A a rustic folk-fiddle from Spain descended from the medieval rebec.

Stringed Instruments.name: Rebab
Stringed Instruments.notes: (also (الرباب , رباب, rebap, rebeb, rababah, or al-rababa)(not to be confused with Rabab) - The rebab usually consists of a small, usually rounded body, the front of which is covered in a membrane such as parchment or sheepskin and has a long neck attached. There is a long thin neck with a pegbox at the end and there are one, two or three strings. There is no fingerboard. The instrument is held upright, either resting on the lap or on the floor. The bow is usually more curved than that of the violin. The rebab, though valued for its voice-like tone, has a very limited range (little over an octave), and was gradually replaced throughout much of the Arab world by the violin and kemenche.

Stringed Instruments.name: Rebec
Stringed Instruments.notes: (sometimes rebeck, and originally various other spellings) A bowed string musical instrument. In its most common form, it has three strings and is played on the arm or under the chin, like a violin. Dates back to the Middle Ages and was particularly popular in the 15th and 16th centuries. The instrument is European, but probably developed from the arabo-islamic instrument, the rebab.

Stringed Instruments.name: Reikin
Stringed Instruments.notes: A metal-stringed koto

Stringed Instruments.name: Requinto Guitar
Stringed Instruments.notes: Has six nylon strings and is about 18% smaller than a standard guitar scale. Requintos made in Mexico have a deeper body than a standard classical guitar (110 mm as opposed to 105 mm). Requintos made in Spain tend to be of the same depth as the standard classical. Requinto guitars are also used throughout Latin America.

Stringed Instruments.name: Resonator Guitar
Stringed Instruments.notes: (also Dobro) - An acoustic guitar whose sound is produced by one or more metal cones (resonators) instead of the wooden soundboard (guitar top/face). Resonator guitars were originally designed to be louder than conventional acoustic guitars which were overwhelmed by horns and percussion instruments in dance orchestras. They became prized for their distinctive sound however, and found life with several musical styles (most notably bluegrass and also blues) well after electric amplification solved the issue of inadequate guitar sound levels.

Stringed Instruments.name: Resonator Mandolin
Stringed Instruments.notes: Also Dobro mandolin: a mandolin whose sound is produced by one or more metal cones (resonators) instead of the customary wooden soundboard.

Stringed Instruments.name: Ronroco
Stringed Instruments.notes: A larger version of a Charango

Stringed Instruments.name: Ruan
Stringed Instruments.notes: Chinese moon shaped, short necked, lute type instrument family. Please use the brackets to give the type - Ruan [Gaoyin], Ruan [Da], Ruan [Zhong], Ruan [Ziao]

Stringed Instruments.name: Rudra Veena
Stringed Instruments.notes: Also rudraveena, rudra vina, and called bīn in northern India: a large veena with two large resonators made from calabash gourds.

Stringed Instruments.name: Sanshin
Stringed Instruments.notes: A three-stringed Okinawan musical instrument with a snakeskin-covered body, the precursor of the mainland Japanese shamisen.

Stringed Instruments.name: Sanxian
Stringed Instruments.notes: (also 三弦) A Chinese lute — a three-stringed fretless plucked musical instrument. It has a long fingerboard, and the body is traditionally made from snakeskin stretched over a rounded rectangular resonator. It is made in several sizes for different purposes and in the late 20th century a four-stringed version was also developed.

Stringed Instruments.name: Sapeh
Stringed Instruments.notes: Also sape', sampek, sambe', sapek: a traditional single-stringed lute carved from a single bole of wood, used by the Kenyah and Kayan people of East Kalimantan and North Kalimantan, Indonesia and Sarawak, Malaysia.

Stringed Instruments.name: Sarangi
Stringed Instruments.notes: A bowed string instrument of India

Stringed Instruments.name: Sarod
Stringed Instruments.notes: Indian classical musical instrument, a 25-stringed lute-like instrument

Stringed Instruments.name: Sazbus
Stringed Instruments.notes: Turkish stringed instrument

Stringed Instruments.name: Semi-Acoustic Guitar
Stringed Instruments.notes: (also Hollow-Body Electric Guitar) - a type of electric guitar with both a sound box and one or more electric pickups. They evolved out of the full-bodied electric f hole archtop guitar. They do not provide enough acoustic volume to for live performance, but can be used "unplugged" for quiet practice.

Stringed Instruments.name: Semistrunnaya Gitara
Stringed Instruments.notes: (Семиструнная гитара) – A Russian seven-string acoustic guitar – "gypsy guitar", also known as semistrunka (семиструнка) – tuned to the open G tuning

Stringed Instruments.name: Setar
Stringed Instruments.notes: A 4-stringed member of the tanbur family of long-necked lutes with a range of more than two and a half octaves, used in Persian traditional music and played with the index finger of the right hand.It resembles the tar both in tuning and playing style.

Stringed Instruments.name: Shahi Baaja
Stringed Instruments.notes: An electrified and slightly modified version of the Indian bulbul tarang, a type of Indian zither to which have been added typewriter keys which depress several of the strings to change their pitch. The modifications also include the addition of 12 additional unfretted strings which serve as an attached swarmandal (drone harp).

Stringed Instruments.name: Sintir
Stringed Instruments.notes: Three stringed bass lute from the Sub-Saharian West African region.

Stringed Instruments.name: Spinet
Stringed Instruments.notes: A smaller type of harpsichord, or other keyboard instrument such as a piano or organ. A spinet is a cheaper and more compact version of the full-size original, used primarily in the home.

Stringed Instruments.name: Steel Guitar
Stringed Instruments.notes: Refers to at least three types of horizontally played guitar: pedal steel guitar, console (or table) steel guitar, and lap steel guitar. For the first two, please use the credit roles Pedal Steel Guitar or Lap Steel Guitar as appropriate. For the third, type of electric steel guitar intermediate between the lap steel guitar and the pedal steel guitar, please enter "Steel Guitar [Console]" or "Steel Guitar [Table]" Please also use this role if the type of steel guitar is not specified on this release.

Stringed Instruments.name: Strings
Stringed Instruments.notes: Generic credit for stringed instruments

Stringed Instruments.name: Stroh Violin
Stringed Instruments.notes: (also violinophone or horn-violin) A violin that amplifies its sound through a metal resonator and metal horns rather than a wooden sound box as on a standard violin. The instrument is named after its German designer, Johannes Matthias Augustus Stroh.

Stringed Instruments.name: Strumstick
Stringed Instruments.notes: A stringed instrument that uses a diatonic scale fretting (the notes of a major scale). The strings are tuned in a drone relationship (octaves and fifth).

Stringed Instruments.name: Suka Biłgorajska
Stringed Instruments.notes: An obsolete string instrument from medieval Poland, with a body similar to a modern viola but with a short and very wide neck. It was played upright resting on the knee, similar to the tenor viol.

Stringed Instruments.name: Surbahar
Stringed Instruments.notes: A plucked string instrument used in the Hindustani classical music of North India. It is related to the better-known sitar but has a lower tone.

Stringed Instruments.name: Svara Mandala
Stringed Instruments.notes: A rare kind of harp used in Indian classical music.

Stringed Instruments.name: Swarmandel
Stringed Instruments.notes: Also spelt Swarmandal and also credited as Indian harp, this is an Indian stringed instrument. The Indian harp is used in many traditional Hindu and Muslim rituals, and is a traditional instrument.

Stringed Instruments.name: Sympitar
Stringed Instruments.notes: A modern form of guitar combining functional aspects of the guitar and the Indian sitar. This instrument has a unique feature: there is a graphite channel which guides a series of "sympathetic" resonating strings through the neck from the bridge up to the headstock. These strings vibrate or resonate against a "jiwari" bridge, which produces the sustaining drone typically associated with Indian music.

Stringed Instruments.name: SynthAxe
Stringed Instruments.notes: A fretted, guitar-like MIDI controller, created in 1986 by Bill Aitken and manufactured in England in the middle to late 1980s.

Stringed Instruments.name: Talharpa
Stringed Instruments.notes: A four-stringed bowed lyre from northern Europe

Stringed Instruments.name: Tambura
Stringed Instruments.notes: Also called Tanpura, Tamboura. Found in various models in Bulgaria, Croatia, and India.

Stringed Instruments.name: Tamburitza
Stringed Instruments.notes: A Balkan stringed instrument similar to a mandolin in shape and sound. Variants include samica (three double strings), bisernica (two double strings and two single strings; four tones), prim (one double string and three single strings; four tones), bas-prim or brac (instrument) (two double strings and two single strings; four tones), celovic (two double strings and two single strings; four tones), celo (four strings), bas or berda (four strings), and the bugarija or kontra (one double string and three single strings; four tones).

Stringed Instruments.name: Tapboard
Stringed Instruments.notes: A guitar-based instrument which uses parts of a shower hose and an egg timer

Stringed Instruments.name: Tar (lute)
Stringed Instruments.notes: A long-necked, waisted lute found in Iran, Azerbaijan, Georgia, Armenia and other areas near the Caucasus region.

Stringed Instruments.name: Tarawangsa
Stringed Instruments.notes: A traditional Sundanese instrument from West Java, Indonesia, with two metal strings.

Stringed Instruments.name: Tea Chest Bass
Stringed Instruments.notes: A simple upright bass using a tea chest as a resonator, usually with a single string.

Stringed Instruments.name: Tenor Violin
Stringed Instruments.notes: An instrument of the 17th and 18th centuries, with a body slightly larger than a modern viola and tuned an octave lower than the standard violin range. Do not confuse with the baritone violin, a modern instrument with the same range but a body similar to that of a violin.

Stringed Instruments.name: Theorbo
Stringed Instruments.notes: A lute with an extended neck and a second peg-box, on which low-range bass strings were strung. It was a main continuo instrument in early Baroque music. A variant is the French théorbe des pièces.

Stringed Instruments.name: Timple
Stringed Instruments.notes: Traditional 5-string plucked string instrument of the Canary Islands

Stringed Instruments.name: Tiple
Stringed Instruments.notes: A small chordophone of the guitar family

Stringed Instruments.name: Tipple
Stringed Instruments.notes: Small ten-stringed instrument

Stringed Instruments.name: Tololoche
Stringed Instruments.notes: The tololoche is a traditional musical instrument from southern Mexico. Its name comes from "tolo loch", from the Mayan language: tolo (bull) and loch (embraced), which would later become tololoche. It is similar to but smaller than the European double bass, and still large enough to produce low-pitched sounds. It has three[1] or four strings, and is plucked with the fingers (pizzicato). It is purely a folk instrument, and not used in classical music.

Stringed Instruments.name: Tonkori
Stringed Instruments.notes: A plucked string instrument played by the Ainu people of Hokkaido, northern Japan and Sakhalin. It is unfretted and has between three and five strings which are not stopped but instead played "open."

Stringed Instruments.name: Torban
Stringed Instruments.notes: A Ukrainian musical instrument that combines the features of the Baroque lute with those of the psaltery. It differs from the theorbo by having additional short unfretted treble strings (known as prystrunky) strung along the treble side of the soundboard.

Stringed Instruments.name: Tovshuur
Stringed Instruments.notes: Also topshur: a two- or three-stringed lute from Western Mongolia.

Stringed Instruments.name: Tumbi
Stringed Instruments.notes: Also toombi, tumba, toomba: a high-pitched, single-string instrument from Punjab made of a wooden stick attached to a gourd shell. The single metallic string is plucked with a continuous flicking motion.

Stringed Instruments.name: Tzouras
Stringed Instruments.notes: Greek instrument. Also known as Dzoura, Dzurato

Stringed Instruments.name: Ukulele
Stringed Instruments.notes: (also Ukelele, also abbreviated as uke.) A Hawaiian interpretation of small Portuguese guitar-like instruments. Ukuleles come in four sizes; Soprano, Concert, Tenor, and Baritone.

Stringed Instruments.name: Ütőgardon
Stringed Instruments.notes: (also Gardon) - a folk musical instrument originating in Transylvania and played by the Székelys and Csángós, a Hungarian ethnic group in Transylvania, with a violin playing a melody. It is similar in appearance to a cello, but it is played percussively. It can have three or four strings, usually tuned to D and d, and is played with a stick instead of a bow, providing a droning accompaniment.

Stringed Instruments.name: Valiha
Stringed Instruments.notes: A bamboo tube zither from Madagascar. It is played by plucking the strings, which may be made of metal or (originally) the bamboo skin which is pried up in long strands and propped up by small bridges.

Stringed Instruments.name: Veena
Stringed Instruments.notes: A plucked stringed instrument used in Indian classical music from Southern India

Stringed Instruments.name: Vielle
Stringed Instruments.notes: A European bowed stringed instrument used in the Medieval period, similar to a modern violin but with a somewhat longer and deeper body, five (rather than four) gut strings, and a leaf-shaped pegbox with frontal tuning pegs.

Stringed Instruments.name: Vihuela
Stringed Instruments.notes: A name given to two different guitar-like string instruments: one from 15th and 16th century Spain, usually with 12 paired strings, and the other, the Mexican vihuela, from 20th century Mexico with five strings and typically played in Mariachi bands.

Stringed Instruments.name: Viol
Stringed Instruments.notes: The viol (also called viola da gamba) is any one of a family of bowed, fretted stringed musical instruments developed in the 1400s and used primarily in the Renaissance and Baroque periods.

Stringed Instruments.name: Viola Braguesa
Stringed Instruments.notes: A stringed instrument similar to a guitar from Braga, north-western Portugal, with 10 paired steel strings.

Stringed Instruments.name: Viola Caipira
Stringed Instruments.notes: Brazilian ten-string guitar with five courses of strings arranged in pairs.

Stringed Instruments.name: Viola d'Amore
Stringed Instruments.notes: A 7- or 6-stringed musical instrument with sympathetic strings used chiefly in the baroque period. It is played under the chin in the same manner as the violin.

Stringed Instruments.name: Viola da Terra
Stringed Instruments.notes: A guitar-like instrument from the Azores, with either 12 strings in six courses or 15 strings in five courses, associated with the saudade genre of Portuguese music.

Stringed Instruments.name: Viola de Cocho
Stringed Instruments.notes: 5-string lute-like viola played in Pantanal region, frontier with Paraguay.

Stringed Instruments.name: Viola Kontra
Stringed Instruments.notes: A three-stringed viola used in Hungarian, Czech, Polish, Romanian, Slovak and Romani dance music. It has a flattened bridge and is used to play chords rather than single notes.

Stringed Instruments.name: Viola Nordestina
Stringed Instruments.notes: 10-string acoustic guitar with vents that kind of make it sound like a dobro. Very common in the Northeastern part of Brazil for regional music.

Stringed Instruments.name: Viola Pomposa
Stringed Instruments.notes: Also violino pomposo: a five-stringed instrument slightly larger than a viola, developed around 1725.

Stringed Instruments.name: Violão de sete cordas
Stringed Instruments.notes: A Brazilian seven-string acoustic guitar used primarily in choro and samba. It is typically tuned like a classical guitar but with an additional C-string below the low E.

Stringed Instruments.name: Violone
Stringed Instruments.notes: Instrument belonging to both the viol and violin families with many variations.

Stringed Instruments.name: Xalam
Stringed Instruments.notes: Also spelled khalam, also called bappe, diassare, hoddu, koliko, komsa, kontigi, koni, konting, molo, ndere, ngoni, and tidinit. a simple lute with one to five strings. The wooden body (soundbox) of the instrument is oval-shaped and covered with the hide of cattle. The strings of the xalam are typically made of two or three tightly wound strands of low-gauge nylon fishing line; these strings are fixed to the instrument's wooden neck by long and narrow leather strips and to its wooden bridge by cotton strings. By moving these strips, the instrument's tune can be adjusted. The xalam usually has two main melody strings that are fingered by the left hand (like the strings of a guitar or banjo) and two to three supplementary strings of fixed pitch.

Stringed Instruments.name: Yang T'Chin
Stringed Instruments.notes: No information available.

Stringed Instruments.name: Yanggeum
Stringed Instruments.notes: A traditional Korean string instrument

Stringed Instruments.name: Yangqin
Stringed Instruments.notes: (also 扬琴, 揚琴, yángqín) A Chinese hammered dulcimer originally from Central Asia (Persia (modern-day Iran)).

Stringed Instruments.name: Zeze
Stringed Instruments.notes: Also tzetze or dzendze in mainland Africa, and lokanga voatavo in Madagascar. An instrument with 3 wire strings, that can be plucked or bowed. The instrument's body is a gourd attached to a stick with three frets carved into it.

Stringed Instruments.name: Zongora
Stringed Instruments.notes: An instrument typical of Maramureş, a region of Romania. It is similar to a guitar, but has fewer strings. In the past it had two strings, but nowadays it has four or even five.

Wind Instruments.name: Accordina
Wind Instruments.notes: Also chromatic button melodica: an instrument, usually made of metal, with the same mechanism and reeds as a melodica but with a keyboard similar to that of a chromatic button accordion.

Wind Instruments.name: Aerophone
Wind Instruments.notes: The brand of a family of digital wind instruments as well as a generic term for any instrument (e.g. wind instruments) in which sound is created by the movement of air without the use of strings or membranes.

Wind Instruments.name: Algoza
Wind Instruments.notes: (also: Jorhi, Ngoza) a Punjabi woodwind instrument adopted by Sindhi folk musicians.

Wind Instruments.name: Alphorn
Wind Instruments.notes: Also called alpenhorn, a wind instrument consisting of a natural wooden horn of conical bore, having a cup-shaped mouthpiece.

Wind Instruments.name: Alto Horn
Wind Instruments.notes: (also: Tenor horn, Althorn, E♭ horn)

Wind Instruments.name: Apito
Wind Instruments.notes: A whistle from Brazil. Unlike the European variety the Apito has two openings at the sides and can thus make three different pitches.

Wind Instruments.name: Arghul
Wind Instruments.notes: (أرغول or يرغول): also argul, arghoul, arghool, argol, yarghul – An ancient single-reed wind instrument still used in Egypt, Palestine, Syria and Jordan.

Wind Instruments.name: Bandoneon
Wind Instruments.notes: A free-reed instrument particularly popular in Argentina

Wind Instruments.name: Bansuri
Wind Instruments.notes: An Indian side-blown flute made of bamboo or reed with six or seven holes

Wind Instruments.name: Barrel Organ
Wind Instruments.notes: A mechanical musical instrument consisting of bellows and one or more ranks of pipes housed in a case, usually of wood, and often highly decorated. The basic principle is the same as a traditional pipe organ, but rather than being played by an organist, the barrel organ is activated either by a person turning a crank, or by clockwork driven by weights or springs. The pieces of music are encoded onto wooden barrels (or cylinders), which are analogous to the keyboard of the traditional pipe organ.

Wind Instruments.name: Basset Clarinet
Wind Instruments.notes: Similar to the soprano clarinet with an extended low range, best known for Mozart's compositions for the instrument. It is typically tuned to A, unlike the similarly named basset horn, which is tuned to a lower pitch (typically F).

Wind Instruments.name: Basset Horn
Wind Instruments.notes: (also basset-horn) A member of the clarinet family. A wind instrument with a single reed and a cylindrical bore. However, the basset horn is larger and has a bend near the mouthpiece rather than an entirely straight body

Wind Instruments.name: Bayan
Wind Instruments.notes: A type of chromatic button accordion developed in Russia in the early 20th century and named after the bard, Boyan. It differs from western chromatic button accordions

Wind Instruments.name: Bellowphone
Wind Instruments.notes: http://www.bellowphone.com/

Wind Instruments.name: Beresta
Wind Instruments.notes: Russian Silver Birch Bark Bird Whistle

Wind Instruments.name: Blues Harp
Wind Instruments.notes: Also called a richter tuned harmonica or 10-hole harmonica (in Asia), is the most widely known type of harmonica. In the United States and Europe, it is called a diatonic harmonica. It has ten holes which offer the player 19 notes (10 holes times a draw and a blow for each hole minus one repeated note) in a three octave range.

Wind Instruments.name: Bombarde
Wind Instruments.notes: A folk musical instrument from Brittany and Cornwall that is a cross between an oboe and a conical-bored pipe chanter

Wind Instruments.name: Border Pipes
Wind Instruments.notes: Also Lowland pipes, reel pipes, half-long pipes: a bagpipe from the Anglo-Scottish Borders region.

Wind Instruments.name: Brass Bass
Wind Instruments.notes: An older term for Bass Tuba which appears on early 20th century records.

Wind Instruments.name: Bucium
Wind Instruments.notes: (also trâmbiţă or tulnic) is a type of alphorn used by mountain dwellers in Romania.

Wind Instruments.name: C Melody Saxophone
Wind Instruments.notes: A saxophone pitched in the key of C, between the alto and tenor. It was popular in the early 1900s but became less common after the 1930s.

Wind Instruments.name: Cabrette
Wind Instruments.notes: Also musette: a bagpipe originating in Auvergne, France, and also played in Haute-Auvergne and Aubrac. Not to be confused with the similarly named chabrette.

Wind Instruments.name: Caramusa
Wind Instruments.notes: A bagpipe from Corsica made of wood, leather and reed.

Wind Instruments.name: Carnyx
Wind Instruments.notes: A bronze trumpet of the Iron Age Celts with an elongated S shape, held so that the long straight tube was vertical and the bell, shaped like an animal's head, was horizontal.

Wind Instruments.name: Chabrette
Wind Instruments.notes: Two related French bagpipes, one from Limousin and a smaller one from Périgord. Not to be confused with the similarly named cabrette from Auvergne.

Wind Instruments.name: Chalumeau
Wind Instruments.notes: A woodwind instrument of the late baroque and early classical era, in appearance rather like a recorder, but with a mouthpiece like a clarinet's.

Wind Instruments.name: Chirimia
Wind Instruments.notes: Predecessor of oboe, used in medieval Europe and in colonial Spanish America.

Wind Instruments.name: Clarín Cajamarquino
Wind Instruments.notes: Also qewayllo, kepa or shukcha. A Peruvian wind instrument made from a single thick reed 3 to 4 metres long, with a bell made from a gourd.

Wind Instruments.name: Clarion
Wind Instruments.notes: (also: claro) A type of cylindrical brass instrument dating from the 11th to 14th centuries. It is the ancestor to the trumpet and was used by cavalries in camp and as a signal during war.

Wind Instruments.name: Claviola
Wind Instruments.notes: Similar to a melodica, but worn like an accordion, the claviola has a set of piano keys on the right side that range 2 1/2 octaves. The left side is a set of pipes that range in length depending on the corresponding pitch.

Wind Instruments.name: Comb
Wind Instruments.notes: A simple combination of a comb and wax paper to form a kazoo like instrument

Wind Instruments.name: Concert Flute
Wind Instruments.notes: (also Western Concert Flute, Transverse Flute, Flute Traversière) - A side-blown woodwind instrument made of metal or wood. It is the most common variant of the flute.

Wind Instruments.name: Concertina
Wind Instruments.notes: A member of the free-reed family of instruments. Concertinas typically have buttons on both ends and are distinguished from an accordion (piano or button) by the direction of their button travel when pushed. Concertina buttons travel in the same direction as the bellows

Wind Instruments.name: Contrabass Trombone
Wind Instruments.notes: The lowest instrument in the trombone family of brass instruments.

Wind Instruments.name: Contrabassoon
Wind Instruments.notes: The contrabassoon, also contrafagotto or double bassoon, is a larger version of the bassoon sounding an octave lower.

Wind Instruments.name: Cor Anglais
Wind Instruments.notes: Also known as English Horn

Wind Instruments.name: Cornett
Wind Instruments.notes: An early wind instrument, dating from the Medieval, Renaissance and Baroque periods. It is not to be confused with the trumpet-like instrument cornet.

Wind Instruments.name: Couesnophone
Wind Instruments.notes: also goofus or queenophone – A free-reed in a shape similar to a saxophone, patented in 1924, which has been described as "a mouth-blown accordion."

Wind Instruments.name: Cromorne
Wind Instruments.notes: French woodwind reed instrument used in the early Baroque period in French court music.

Wind Instruments.name: Crumhorn
Wind Instruments.notes: A musical instrument of the woodwind family, a capped reed instrument. A double reed is mounted inside a windcap at one end of a long pipe. Blowing into the windcap produces a musical note. The pitch of the note can be varied by opening or closing finger holes along the length of the pipe.

Wind Instruments.name: Daegeum
Wind Instruments.notes: (also spelled taegum or taegŭm) is a large bamboo transverse flute used in traditional Korean music. It has a buzzing membrane that gives it a special timbre.

Wind Instruments.name: Danso
Wind Instruments.notes: A Korean notched, end-blown vertical bamboo flute used in Korean folk music.

Wind Instruments.name: Didgeridoo
Wind Instruments.notes: Also spelt Didjeridu

Wind Instruments.name: Dili Tuiduk
Wind Instruments.notes: also( дилли туйдук, dilli düdük, dilli tuyduk , dili tüidük, dilli tüidük) is a Turkmen woodwind instrument. It is a clarinet-like, single-reed instrument used mainly in Turkmen folk music.

Wind Instruments.name: Dizi
Wind Instruments.notes: (also dízi di 笛, hengdi 橫笛, has varieties including the qudi 曲笛 and bangdi 梆笛), is a Chinese transverse flute, it is a major Chinese musical instrument, and is widely used in many genres of Chinese folk music, as well as Chinese opera, and the modern Chinese orchestra.

Wind Instruments.name: Dord
Wind Instruments.notes: An ancient bronze horn native to Ireland.

Wind Instruments.name: Duduk
Wind Instruments.notes: A traditional woodwind instrument of Armenian origins.[1][2] This English word is often used generically for a family of ethnic instruments including the doudouk or duduk (դուդուկ) (previously dziranapogh (ծիրանափող, literally "apricot horn") in Armenia, the düdük or mey in Turkey, the duduki in Georgia, the balaban in Azerbaijan, the narmeh-ney in Iran, the duduka or dudka in Russia and Ukraine, duduk in Serbia, and the daduk in Bulgaria.

Wind Instruments.name: Dulcian
Wind Instruments.notes: Predecessor of bassoon (actually called "bajón" in Spanish).

Wind Instruments.name: Dulzaina
Wind Instruments.notes: Spanish wind instrument (not to be confused with *dulcian*), somewhat similar to Chirimia.

Wind Instruments.name: Dvojačka
Wind Instruments.notes: Also dvojačky, dvojanka, dvojacka. A double-core flute traditional to Slovakia, that combines a 6-hole shepherd's flute with an overtone flute.

Wind Instruments.name: Electronic Valve Instrument
Wind Instruments.notes: (also EVI) - A controller intended to be played by brass instrumentalists.

Wind Instruments.name: Electronic Wind Instrument
Wind Instruments.notes: (also EWI) - A combination of a controller and synthesizer that lets wind musicians (for example saxophonists) play electronic synthesizers using their breath and fingering technique.

Wind Instruments.name: English Horn
Wind Instruments.notes: Also known as Cor Anglais

Wind Instruments.name: Euphonium
Wind Instruments.notes: A conical-bore, tenor-voiced brass instrument.

Wind Instruments.name: Fife
Wind Instruments.notes: A small, high-pitched, transverse flute that is similar to the piccolo, but louder and shriller due to its narrower bore. The fife originated in medieval Europe and is often used in military and marching bands. Someone who plays the fife is called a fifer. The word fife comes from the German Pfeife, or pipe, ultimately derived from the Latin word pipare.

Wind Instruments.name: Flageolet
Wind Instruments.notes: A woodwind instrument and a member of the fipple flute family

Wind Instruments.name: Flugabone
Wind Instruments.notes: A mix of trombone and flugelhorn

Wind Instruments.name: Fluier
Wind Instruments.notes: A Romanian 6 hole pipe similar to a tin whistle, but made out of wood.

Wind Instruments.name: Free-reed Flute
Wind Instruments.notes: A single tube with finger-holes and a mouthpiece with a metal free reed, found in many forms throughout south-east Asia.

Wind Instruments.name: Gaita
Wind Instruments.notes: A family of bagpipes from various regions of Spain and Portugal. Examples include the Asturian gaita, the Galician gaita, the Portuguese gaita transmontana, the Aragonese gaita de boto.

Wind Instruments.name: Garklein Recorder
Wind Instruments.notes: also known as the sopranissimo recorder or piccolo recorder.

Wind Instruments.name: Gemshorn
Wind Instruments.notes: An instrument of the ocarina family that was historically made from the horn of a chamois, goat, or other suitable animal.

Wind Instruments.name: Gralla
Wind Instruments.notes: Also grall de pastor, xaramita or xirimita. A traditional Catalan double-reed instrument in the shawm family.

Wind Instruments.name: Gudastviri
Wind Instruments.notes: droneless, double-chantered, horn-belled bagpipe played in Georgia. Also known as the chiboni, stviri, or tulumi.

Wind Instruments.name: Harmet
Wind Instruments.notes: Finnish flute

Wind Instruments.name: Harmonica
Wind Instruments.notes: A free reed wind instrument which is played by blowing air into it or drawing air out by placing lips over individual holes (reed chambers) or multiple holes. The pressure caused by blowing or drawing air into the reed chambers causes a reed or multiple reeds to vibrate up and down creating sound. Each chamber has multiple, variable-tuned brass or bronze reeds which are secured at one end and loose on the other end, with the loose end vibrating and creating sound. The harmonica is used in blues and American folk music, jazz, classical music, country music, rock and roll, and pop music. The harmonica has other nicknames, especially in blues music, including: "harp," "blues harp," and "mouth organ."

Wind Instruments.name: Heckelphone
Wind Instruments.notes: A double reed instrument of the oboe family, but with a wider bore and hence a heavier and more penetrating tone. It is pitched an octave below the oboe. Approximately four feet in length, and is quite heavy, it rests on the floor, supported by a short metal peg attached to the underside of its bulbous bell. (An alternate second bell, called a "muting" bell, is also available, which serves to muffle the instrument for playing in a small ensemble.)

Wind Instruments.name: Helicon
Wind Instruments.notes: Tuba-like brass instrument. Predecessor to the sousaphone, which was an improved version with a different shape.

Wind Instruments.name: Hichiriki
Wind Instruments.notes: 篳篥 (Japanese flute)

Wind Instruments.name: Horagai
Wind Instruments.notes: Horagai (also 法螺貝. jinkai, 陣貝) - Large conch shells that have been used as a trumpets in Japan for many centuries. The instrument, which has served a number of purposes throughout Japanese history, has been given a number of Japanese names depending on its function. Special schools still teach students to play the traditional music associated with the conch.

Wind Instruments.name: Horn
Wind Instruments.notes: Please use French Horn, Alphorn, Cor Anglais, Crumhorn, English Horn, and Flugelhorn if these are specifically used.

Wind Instruments.name: Hotchiku
Wind Instruments.notes: A Japanese flute, manufactured solely from bamboo. Reminiscent of the Shakuhachi flute, but is larger and has a more brittle tone.

Wind Instruments.name: Hulusi
Wind Instruments.notes: Also huluxi, pi lamtao, pi namtao: a Chinese free-reed instrument made from three bamboo pipes passing through a Calabash gourd.

Wind Instruments.name: Irish Flute
Wind Instruments.notes: A conical-bore, simple-system wooden flute adapted from the type favoured by classical flautists of the early 19th century and used in Irish and other Celtic traditional music.

Wind Instruments.name: Jug
Wind Instruments.notes: A jug (usually made of glass or stoneware) played with the mouth. With an embouchure like that used for a brass instrument, the musician holds the mouth of the jug about an inch from his or her mouth and emits a blast of sound, made by a "buzzing" of the lips, directly into it. The jug does not touch the musician's mouth, but serves as a resonating chamber to amplify and enrich the sound made by the musician's lips. Changes in pitch are controlled by loosening or tightening the lips, and an accomplished jugplayer might have a two octave range.

Wind Instruments.name: Kagurabue
Wind Instruments.notes: 神楽笛 (Japanese side-blown flute)

Wind Instruments.name: Kaval
Wind Instruments.notes: A chromatic end-blown flute traditionally played throughout Azerbaijan, Turkey, Bulgaria, Republic of Macedonia, Kosovo / Serbia (Kavall), northern Greece (Kavali or Dzhamara), southern Romania (Caval), Armenia (Բլուլ or Blul) and Kurdistan (Blul).

Wind Instruments.name: Kawala
Wind Instruments.notes: (كاوالا or كولة), also salamiya (سلامية) – An end-blown cane flute used in Arabic music, similar to the ney but with six finger holes.

Wind Instruments.name: Kazoo
Wind Instruments.notes: A simple musical instrument (membranophone) that adds a "buzzing" timbral quality to a player's voice when one hums into it.

Wind Instruments.name: Khene
Wind Instruments.notes: A mouth-organ whose pipes are connected with a small, hollowed-out wooden reservoir into which air is blown. Associated with the Lao of Laos and Northeast Thailand, similar instruments date back to the bronze age of Southeast Asia.

Wind Instruments.name: Kortholt
Wind Instruments.notes: Renaissance period woodwind instrument

Wind Instruments.name: Launeddas
Wind Instruments.notes: A very ancient woodwind instrument from Sardinia, Italy. Consists of three pipes of different length, played with circular respiration.

Wind Instruments.name: Limbe
Wind Instruments.notes: A Mongolian end-blown flute

Wind Instruments.name: Liru
Wind Instruments.notes: A traditional clarinet-like instrument from Karelia. Manufactured from aspen or alder trees, length varies from 25 to 50 centimeters.

Wind Instruments.name: Low Whistle
Wind Instruments.notes: (also concert whistle) A variation of the traditional tin whistle / pennywhistle, distinguished by its lower pitch and larger size.

Wind Instruments.name: Lur
Wind Instruments.notes: The more recent type is made of wood and was in use in Scandinavia during the Middle Ages. The older type, named after the more recent type, is made of bronze, dates to the Bronze Age and was often found in pairs, deposited in bogs, mainly in Denmark.

Wind Instruments.name: Lyricon
Wind Instruments.notes: An electronic wind instrument. It enabled instrumentalists to control a synthesizer by playing a type of electronic saxophone, the synthesizer being contained in a fur-lined plastic case.

Wind Instruments.name: Mänkeri
Wind Instruments.notes: A traditional clarinet-like instrument from Western Finland. Manufactured from pinewood, length varies from 10 to 30 centimeters.

Wind Instruments.name: Mellophone
Wind Instruments.notes: The mellophone is a brass instrument that is typically used in place of the horn in marching bands or drum and bugle corps.

Wind Instruments.name: Melodeon
Wind Instruments.notes: (also diatonic button accordion) - A type of button accordion where the melody-side keyboard is limited to the notes of diatonic scales in a small number of keys (sometimes only one). The bass side usually contains the principal chords of the instrument's key and the root notes of those chords.

Wind Instruments.name: Mey
Wind Instruments.notes: Double-reed aerophone used in Turkish folk music

Wind Instruments.name: Mizmar
Wind Instruments.notes: In Arabic music, a mizmar is any single or double reed wind instrument. In Egypt mizmar usually refers to a surnay. Mizmar is also a term used for a group of musicians, usually a duo or trio, that play a mizmar instrument along with an accompaniment of one or two double-sided bass drums.

Wind Instruments.name: Mizwad
Wind Instruments.notes: (Also: mezoued, mizwid, مِزْود, مَزاود, mazāwid) a type of bagpipes played in Tunisia

Wind Instruments.name: Moceño
Wind Instruments.notes: (also Moxeño, Mozeño) - a flute used by the people in the Andes. It's played like a travers flute but the mouth is not directly on the flute. The mouth is a separate piece that goes to the left, as the flute itself goes to the right.

Wind Instruments.name: Mouth Organ
Wind Instruments.notes: Relative to the Harmonica / Melodica

Wind Instruments.name: Murli
Wind Instruments.notes: Murli – Also pungi, murala, been: An aerophonic double reed Instrument made of bamboo pipe and gourd shell. It is the instrument that was used in snake-charming.

Wind Instruments.name: Musette
Wind Instruments.notes: (also Oboe Musette) - the smallest member of the shawm family. Shawms were the renaissance/early baroque version of the oboe. [not a Musette de Cour - use the credit "Bagpipes"].

Wind Instruments.name: Nadaswaram
Wind Instruments.notes: (also nadhaswaram, nagaswaram) Classical instruments of South India, a wind instrument similar to the North Indian shehnai but larger, with a hardwood body and a large flaring bell made of wood or metal.

Wind Instruments.name: Ney
Wind Instruments.notes: (also Nay) - End-blown flute that figures prominently in Middle Eastern music

Wind Instruments.name: Nose Flute
Wind Instruments.notes: A popular musical instrument played in Polynesia and the Pacific Rim countries. Other versions are found in Africa, China and India.

Wind Instruments.name: Oboe d'Amore
Wind Instruments.notes: A woodwind instrument. It is a member of the double reed family, very similar to the oboe. Slightly larger than the oboe, it has a less assertive and more tranquil and serene tone, and is considered the mezzo-soprano or alto of the oboe family.

Wind Instruments.name: Ocarina
Wind Instruments.notes: Sometimes called the sweet potato, an ancient flute-like wind instrument. It usually is made up of an oval-shaped enclosed space and four to thirteen finger holes, though there are some variations on the standard design.

Wind Instruments.name: Ophicleide
Wind Instruments.notes: A family of conical bore, brass keyed bugles, and an early ancestor of the saxophone.

Wind Instruments.name: Panpipes
Wind Instruments.notes: Also called Bolivian Pipes

Wind Instruments.name: Piano Accordion
Wind Instruments.notes: An accordion equipped with a right-hand keyboard similar to a piano or organ.

Wind Instruments.name: Pifana
Wind Instruments.notes: A type of gemshorn from Corsica, usually made from goat horn.

Wind Instruments.name: Pipe
Wind Instruments.notes: A wide range of instruments used especially in folk music. There are many specific types of pipes known, just to name Piszczałka (Poland), Fujara (Slovakia), Fluieraş (Romania), Zhaleika (Russia).

Wind Instruments.name: Piri
Wind Instruments.notes: A cylindrical oboe with a bamboo body.

Wind Instruments.name: Pirula
Wind Instruments.notes: A reed recorder from Corsica.

Wind Instruments.name: Pito
Wind Instruments.notes: A wooden flute used in the Andes. The mouth and the body are made of one piece. The sound of it is sharp and high.

Wind Instruments.name: Pito Herreño
Wind Instruments.notes: A small metal whistle/flute typical of El Hierro in the Canary Islands.

Wind Instruments.name: Pixiephone
Wind Instruments.notes: A children's toy sold in the UK in the 1960s and 1970s, similar to the Melodica.

Wind Instruments.name: Pommer
Wind Instruments.notes: Also bombard, hautbois, bombardo, bombardone: the alto, tenor, bass, and contrabass members of the shawm family. Do not confuse with the Breton bombarde.

Wind Instruments.name: Quena
Wind Instruments.notes: (also Kena, Qina) - traditional flute of the Andes. Usually made of bamboo, it has 6 finger holes and one thumb hole and is open on both ends. To produce sound, the player closes the top end of the pipe with the flesh between his chin and lower lip, and blows a stream of air downward, along the axis of the pipe, over an elliptical notch cut into the end. It is normally in the key of G, with G being the lowest note (all holes covered). It produces a very breathy or airy tone.

Wind Instruments.name: Quenacho
Wind Instruments.notes: (also Kenacho) South American (Andean) flute, a greater, lower-toned version of the quena.

Wind Instruments.name: Rackett
Wind Instruments.notes: Also cervelas or sausage bassoon: a Renaissance-era double-reed wind instrument, introduced late in the sixteenth century.

Wind Instruments.name: Rauschpfeife
Wind Instruments.notes: A wooden double-reed instrument with the reed enclosed in a windcap

Wind Instruments.name: Recorder
Wind Instruments.notes: A woodwind musical instrument of the family known as fipple flutes, blockflutes or internal duct flutes. The recorder is end-blown and the mouth of the instrument is constricted by a wooden plug, known as a block or fipple.

Wind Instruments.name: Reeds
Wind Instruments.notes: For the general crediting of reed instruments.

Wind Instruments.name: Rhaita
Wind Instruments.notes: (also Ghaita) - A reed instrument from Northern Africa

Wind Instruments.name: Rondador
Wind Instruments.notes: A set of chorded bamboo panpipes that produces two tones simultaneously. It consists of pieces of cane, placed side by side in order by size and closed at one end, and is played by blowing across the top of the instrument. The rondador is considered the national instrument of Ecuador.

Wind Instruments.name: Rozhok
Wind Instruments.notes: (also vladimirskiy rozhok,Rojok, Владимирский Рожок) An ancient Russian musical instrument made of wood. A rozhok is a conical straight tube with the five playing holes on the top of it and one - below. At the low end is a small bell at the top the pasted in mouthpiece. The total length of a rozhok ranges from 320 to 830 mm. A mouthpiece is cut in the form of a small cap and the lower end of the tube is in the form of a conic bell.

Wind Instruments.name: Ryuteki
Wind Instruments.notes: (龍笛, literally "dragon flute") is a Japanese transverse fue made of bamboo. It is used in gagaku, the Shinto classical music associated with Japan's imperial court.

Wind Instruments.name: Sackbut
Wind Instruments.notes: Predecessor of trombone used in Renaissance and Baroqque times, it has a softer sound.

Wind Instruments.name: Saenghwang
Wind Instruments.notes: Also saeng: a Korean mouth-blown free-reed instrument consisting of 17 bamboo pipes. It is similar to the Chinese sheng, but with different tuning.

Wind Instruments.name: Sampona
Wind Instruments.notes: (also Sampoña, Zampoña, or Siku), an Andean pan flute.

Wind Instruments.name: Sarrusophone
Wind Instruments.notes: A family of transposing musical instruments, its intended use was to serve as a replacement for the oboe and bassoon.

Wind Instruments.name: Saxello
Wind Instruments.notes: Essentially a straight soprano sax, but with a slightly curved neck and tipped bell.

Wind Instruments.name: Schwyzerörgeli
Wind Instruments.notes: A type of accordion used in Swiss folk music

Wind Instruments.name: Serpent
Wind Instruments.notes: A bass wind instrument, descended from the cornett, and a distant ancestor of the tuba, with a mouthpiece like a brass instrument but side holes like a woodwind. It is usually a long cone bent into a snakelike shape, hence the name.

Wind Instruments.name: Shakuhachi
Wind Instruments.notes: Japanese bamboo flute

Wind Instruments.name: Shanai
Wind Instruments.notes: (also Shehnai, Shenai) - a tube-like instrument that gradually widens towards the lower end. It usually has between six and nine holes. It employs two sets of double reeds, making it a quadruple reed woodwind. By controlling the breath, various tunes can be played on it.

Wind Instruments.name: Shawm
Wind Instruments.notes: (also possably Bass-Shalm ?) A medieval and Renaissance musical instrument of the woodwind family made in Europe from the late 13th century until the 17th century. It was developed from the oriental zurna and is the predecessor of the modern oboe.

Wind Instruments.name: Shenai
Wind Instruments.notes: Indian reed instrument

Wind Instruments.name: Sheng
Wind Instruments.notes: A mouth-blown free reed instrument (the first) consisting essentially of vertical pipes.

Wind Instruments.name: Shinobue
Wind Instruments.notes: A Japanese flute, very important in Noh and Kabuki theatre, as well as in shinto and folk music.

Wind Instruments.name: Shofar
Wind Instruments.notes: An ancient instrument typically made of a ram's horn, used in Jewish religious ceremonies.

Wind Instruments.name: Shruti Box
Wind Instruments.notes: A small wooden instrument that traditionally works on a system of bellows. It is similar to a harmonium and is used to provide a drone in a practice session or concert of Indian classical music. It is used as an accompaniment to other instruments and notably the flute.

Wind Instruments.name: Slide Trumpet
Wind Instruments.notes: An early type of trumpet fitted with a single movable section of tubing. This evolved into the sackbut, with the addition of a second joint in the U-shaped slide, and eventually into the modern-day trombone.

Wind Instruments.name: Slide Whistle
Wind Instruments.notes: (also: swanee, swannee whistle, piston flute, jazz flute)

Wind Instruments.name: Sodina
Wind Instruments.notes: Relative of flute

Wind Instruments.name: Sopilka
Wind Instruments.notes: (also; Cопiлка, Сопел) A name applied to a variety of woodwind instruments of the flute family used by Ukrainian folk instrumentalists.

Wind Instruments.name: Sopranissimo Saxophone
Wind Instruments.notes: Also piccolo saxophone, soprillo saxophone.

Wind Instruments.name: Soprano Recorder
Wind Instruments.notes: also known as the descant recorder.

Wind Instruments.name: Souna
Wind Instruments.notes: A Chinese a double reed instrument.

Wind Instruments.name: Sousaphone
Wind Instruments.notes: A type of tuba that is widely employed in marching bands. Designed so that it fits around the body of the tubist and is supported by the left shoulder, the sousaphone may be readily played while being carried.

Wind Instruments.name: Steirische Harmonika
Wind Instruments.notes: A type of diatonic button accordion used in the alpine folk music of Slovenia, the Czech Republic, Austria, Bavaria and the Tyrol.

Wind Instruments.name: Suling
Wind Instruments.notes: An Indonesian/Philippine flute made out of bamboo used in gamelan ensembles.

Wind Instruments.name: Suona
Wind Instruments.notes: (also Dida, Laba) - An ancient double-reed wind instrument. It was introduced into China from Persia and Arabia during the Ming dynasty (A.D. 1368-1644). The mouthpiece of suona is made of two small and thin pieces of reeds. The middle section is a metal bell. Its tone is sonorous and penetrating. The instrument is famous for its capacity to depict joyous and vigorous moods. Its role at first was to inspire the army of the Ming dynasty. Gradually it came to be commonly used in wedding and funeral ceremonies, orchestral, and theatrical music.

Wind Instruments.name: Svirel
Wind Instruments.notes: (свирель), also sopel, sopilka (сопiлка), tsevnitsa, dudka (дудка) – An end-blown wooden flute traditionally used in Russia, Belarus, and Ukraine.

Wind Instruments.name: Taepyungso
Wind Instruments.notes: A conical oboe with a wooden body and metal bell.

Wind Instruments.name: Tambin
Wind Instruments.notes: Also sereendu, fulannu or Fulani flute: a diagonal diatonic flute of the West African Fula people with three finger-holes similar in sound to the ney.

Wind Instruments.name: Tarka
Wind Instruments.notes: An indigenous wooden blockflute of the Andes with 6 finger-holes.

Wind Instruments.name: Tárogató
Wind Instruments.notes: A single reed instrument. It is made out of wood and has a conical bore, similar to the soprano saxophone.

Wind Instruments.name: Tenora
Wind Instruments.notes: A tenor shawm from Catalogia.

Wind Instruments.name: Ti-tse
Wind Instruments.notes: (also Ti) - A traditional Chinese bamboo flute.

Wind Instruments.name: Tible
Wind Instruments.notes: A treble shawm from Catalogia.

Wind Instruments.name: Tin Whistle
Wind Instruments.notes: Also called the tinwhistle, whistle, pennywhistle, or Irish whistle, is a simple six-holed woodwind instrument.

Wind Instruments.name: Traverso
Wind Instruments.notes: Predecessor of the concert flute, mostly made in wood (or ivory for luxury versions) instead of metal. It doesn't have keys/valves, just holes. Also has a conical bore instead of the mostly straight bore of the concert flute.

Wind Instruments.name: Trutruka
Wind Instruments.notes: A coiled trumpet made of bamboo, used by the Mapuche of Chile and Argentina.

Wind Instruments.name: Tsuur
Wind Instruments.notes: Also choor or chuur: a Mongolian end-blown flute without a mouthpiece, usually made from light wood.

Wind Instruments.name: Tussefløyte
Wind Instruments.notes: A Norwegian recorder with a conical bore and slightly different intonation from other recorders.

Wind Instruments.name: Valve Trombone
Wind Instruments.notes: Also trumbone, trombonium.

Wind Instruments.name: Wagner Tuba
Wind Instruments.notes: Brass instrument that combines tonal elements of both the French horn and the trombone.

Wind Instruments.name: Washint
Wind Instruments.notes: Also Washnt: an end-blown wooden flute from Ethiopia.

Wind Instruments.name: Whistling Water Jar
Wind Instruments.notes: An ancient instrument, usually made from pottery, containing water that changes and / or produces the sound.

Wind Instruments.name: Wind
Wind Instruments.notes: To be used for general wind instruments, when a specific instrument is not specified. Also see Brass and Woodwind for more specific generalisations!

Wind Instruments.name: Xiao
Wind Instruments.notes: Chinese bamboo flute

Wind Instruments.name: Yorgaphone
Wind Instruments.notes: A reed instrument from Romania

Wind Instruments.name: Zhaleika
Wind Instruments.notes: (also Jaleika) A Russian single-reed woodwind instrument

Wind Instruments.name: Zukra
Wind Instruments.notes: a Libyan bagpipe with a double-chanter terminating in two cow horns.

Wind Instruments.name: Zurna
Wind Instruments.notes: (also surnay, birbynė, lettish horn, surla, sornai, zournas, zurma) is an multinational outdoor wind instrument, usually accompanied by a davul (bass drum) in Anatolian folk music.

Technical Musical.name: Electronics
Technical Musical.notes: The general manipulation of electronic instruments and effects

Technical Musical.name: Groovebox
Technical Musical.notes: A self-contained instrument for the production of live, loop-based electronic music. A groovebox consists of three integrated elements; one or more sound sources, such as a drum machine, a synthesizer or a sampler; a music sequencer; and a control surface.

Technical Musical.name: MIDI Controller
Technical Musical.notes: The most common MIDI Controller is the standard keyboard, but MIDI notes can be triggered from almost any imaginable device; electronic drums, wind controllers, breaking light beams etc.

Technical Musical.name: Sequencer
Technical Musical.notes: An electronic device that can be programmed to store sequences of rhythms or music.

Technical Musical.name: Talkbox
Technical Musical.notes: (also Talk Box, Voice Box) A musical sound effects device that allows a musician to modify the sound of a musical instrument. The musician controls the modification by changing the shape of their mouth. Usually an effects pedal that sits on the floor and contains a speaker attached with an air tight connection to a plastic tube

Technical Musical.name: Turntables
Technical Musical.notes: Also called decks, phonograph, record player, or gramophone

Technical Musical.name: Vocoder
Technical Musical.notes: A speech analyzer and synthesizer. A vocoder has two inputs, and combines them such that, for example, a synthesized tone input is filtered to follow the spectral profile of the voice input. Other input combinations can be used for different results.

Other Musical.name: Accompanied By
Other Musical.notes: Generic credit for backing musicians. Specific roles should be used instead if known.

Other Musical.name: Audio Generator
Other Musical.notes: An unspecified instrument, presumed to be an electronic device such as a test signal generator.

Other Musical.name: Backing Band
Other Musical.notes: Used to credit the whole band, common on reggae releases.

Other Musical.name: Bass
Other Musical.notes: Generic credit for the playing of a bass instrument or generating bass sounds. Please use a more specific credit where possible, such as Electric Bass for the standard bass guitar, Double Bass or Contrabass for the upright acoustic instrument, Acoustic Bass for the bass version of the acoustic guitar, Electric Upright Bass for the electrified double bass, and Arco Bass, Bass Vocals, Bass Drum, Guitarrón, Bass Clarinet, Bass Harmonica, Bass Saxophone for their specific instruments.

Other Musical.name: Basso Continuo
Other Musical.notes: Common in music from the Baroque era, this is an improvised bass line and chord progression played by a group of instruments to provide the harmonic structure in an orchestral piece.

Other Musical.name: Bullroarer
Other Musical.notes: A longish piece of cord fixed to an oval piece of wood or other suitable material which usually is thicker in the center, and sharpish at the edges.

Other Musical.name: Concert Band
Other Musical.notes: A concert band, also called wind band, symphonic band, symphonic winds, wind orchestra, wind symphony, wind ensemble, or symphonic wind ensemble, is a performing ensemble consisting of several members of the woodwind instrument family, brass instrument family, and percussion instrument family.

Other Musical.name: Concertino
Other Musical.notes: A soloist who is part of a group of soloists within an ensemble (as opposed to a soloist who plays with an ensemble).

Other Musical.name: Devil's Fiddle
Other Musical.notes: Also devil's violin, bladder fiddle, stamp fiddle, bumbass, Teufelsgeige, Bettelgeige, basse de Flandre, Diabelskie skrzypce: a folk instrument used in carnival processions, consisting of a long stick with various objects attached to make different noises. Originally this was a simple fiddle with one or more strings stretched over a pig's-bladder resonator. More recently, however, the bladder has been replaced with percussion instruments such as tambourine, cymbals, bells, played both by stamping the instrument against the ground and by tapping it with a smaller stick.

Other Musical.name: E-Bow
Other Musical.notes: This is not an instrument in its own right, as it does not make any sound on its own. It is a battery-powered hand-held electronic device, which effectively gives a performer another method for playing any stringed instrument. As it uses a magnetic field, it only works on steel strings, so is usually only credited for steel-stringed instruments.

Other Musical.name: Ensemble
Other Musical.notes: A musical ensemble is a group of two or more musicians who perform instrumental or vocal music. In each musical style or genre, different norms have developed for the sizes and composition of different ensembles, and for the repertoire of songs or musical works that these ensembles perform. Can be expanded on with brackets, for example "Ensemble [Quartet]"

Other Musical.name: Gamelan
Other Musical.notes: A musical ensemble from Indonesia, typically from the islands of Bali or Java, featuring a variety of instruments such as metallophones, xylophones, drums and gongs; bamboo flutes, bowed and plucked strings. Vocalists may also be included.

Other Musical.name: Gizmotron
Other Musical.notes: A mechanical bowing device for guitars and bass

Other Musical.name: Glass Harmonica
Other Musical.notes: A mechanized version of the glass harp, invented by Benjamin Franklin, in which a series of glass bowls or discs of different sizes held on a spindle are rubbed to create different notes.

Other Musical.name: Glass Harp
Other Musical.notes: Also musical glasses, singing glasses: a set of upright wine glasses tuned to different pitches, usually by placing different amounts of water into them, which is played either by rubbing fingers over the rims or by using a bow.

Other Musical.name: Guest
Other Musical.notes: A musician or vocalist that is a non-band member.

Other Musical.name: Homus
Other Musical.notes: A version of Jew's Harp from Asia.

Other Musical.name: Instruments
Other Musical.notes: A general credit for the playing of musical instruments

Other Musical.name: Jew's Harp
Other Musical.notes: Also jaw harp, jaws harp, Jew's trump, guimbarde, juice harp, or mouth harp - A flexible metal or bamboo tongue or reed attached to a frame. The tongue/reed is placed in the performer's mouth and plucked with the finger to produce a note. The frame is held against the performer's teeth or lips, using the jaw (thus "jaw harp") and mouth as a resonator, greatly increasing the volume of the instrument. The note thus produced is constant in pitch, though by changing the shape of his or her mouth and the amount of air contained in it the performer can cause different overtones to sound and thus create melodies.

Other Musical.name: Mbira
Other Musical.notes: (also Likembe, Sanza, Zanza, Mbila, Thumb Piano, Mbira Huru, Mbira Njari, Mbira Nyunga Nyunga, Karimba or Kalimba) A wooden board or box to which staggered metal or wooden keys have been attached.

Other Musical.name: Morchang
Other Musical.notes: A brass horseshoe shaped ring with a metal tongue that is made to vibrate with the hands and teeth to mimic speech. (like a mouth harp)

Other Musical.name: Performer
Other Musical.notes: A generic musical role, use brackets to add specifics

Other Musical.name: Siren
Other Musical.notes: Sirens are used as musical instruments, such as in Edgard Varèse's Hyperprism (1924), Ionisation (1931), recorded, in his Poeme Electronique (1958), George Antheil's "Ballet Mécanique" (1926), The Klaxon: March of the Automobiles (1929 by Henry Fillmore, The Chemical Brothers's Song to the Siren and, (in a CBS News 60 Minutes segment) by experimental percussionist Evelyn Glennie.

Other Musical.name: Soloist
Other Musical.notes: This is a musical role, rather than the more common instrument credit used for musicians on Discogs. It denotes that the musician has taken a solo on the track - where one performer is playing either completely alone, or with accompaniment from the others. Common examples are jazz improvisation, featured musicians in classical music, and lead guitar in rock. Please also include the instrument they are playing, as a separate credit, if noted on the release, for example "Soloist, Guitar - Jimi Hendrix"

Other Musical.name: Sounds
Other Musical.notes: General credit sometimes used in a non-specific way on releases, for example Additional Sounds, All sounds by, Sound sources etc

Other Musical.name: Taonga pūoro
Other Musical.notes: The collective name for the Māori traditional musical instruments. These include kōauau and pūtōrino (flutes), hue (blown gourds), pūtātara (a trumpet made from a shell), pūkāea (a long wooden trumpet), tumutumu (pieces of stone, wood or bone that are tapped with strikers), poi (balls of dried flax on string that are swung and tapped), and porotiti and pūrerehua (discs on a cord which are spun).

Other Musical.name: Tifa Totobuang
Other Musical.notes: A music ensemble from the Maluku Islands consisting of totobuang (gong chimes) and a set of tifa drums.

Other Musical.name: Toy
Other Musical.notes: Generic role for the use of toy instruments.

Other Musical.name: Trautonium
Other Musical.notes: A monophonic electronic musical instrument

Other Musical.name: Wobble Board
Other Musical.notes: An instrument popularized by the Australian musician and artist Rolf Harris. Wobble boards are not commercially made, and most are made by the player. Almost any large, rigid but flexible sheet of material can be used as an impromptu wobble board, although some materials are markedly better than others.
